speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, people with disabilities were disappointed to learn of all the amendments that were not included in yesterday's omnibus bill.
They were disappointed that there were no amendments to the Immigration Act, the Broadcasting Act, or the Evidence Act. They were disappointed with the very limited amendments to the National Transportation Act.
They wanted to see deadlines, timetables and enforcement mechanisms. Instead they got promises of further review, further consultation and further delay.
The concerns of disabled Canadians are not recent. They have been discussing these issues with the government for many years. After all this time, disabled Canadians expected a much more substantive and comprehensive bill.
Once again we have a very fancy press kit but the content is not very impressive.

Mr. Speaker, the government has recently announced a half billion dollar action plan to combat child poverty which includes a substantial budget for community based child development initiatives.
This will provide funding for self-help groups and community based agencies to establish prevention and
development initiatives similar to those recommended by the subcommittee on poverty. These will improve the quality of life and opportunities for high-risk children, in particular, the 20 per cent of poor children who experience long-term poverty.
Municipal infrastructure spending, a national school lunch program, a national day care program, anti-business economic policies would do little to help these very needy children who suffer disproportionately from unhealthy pregnancies, poor nutrition, learning disorders, poor health, dangerous environments, cultural and sensory deprivation, isolation, loneliness and negative selfimages.
Big governments do not have the answers. Thousands of local agencies and community groups have long lists of projects and ideas, many of which were included in the poverty report. These will give those children a sense that they are valued, cared for and will give them brighter futures.

Mr. Speaker,
the world recently marked the sixth anniversary of the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl in Ukraine.
In Ukraine, evidence continues to mount that the environmental and human damage from the accident is far greater than what various pro-nuclear institutions would have us believe.
The International Atomic Energy Agency did a study in Ukraine but ignored the two groups most affected by the event, the evacuees and those who helped in the clean-up.
According to Dr. Panov, spokesperson for an officially accredited NGO at a recent conference in New York in preparation for UNCED, some 8,000 young men who worked on the clean-up have since died from various diseases caused by radiation. Yet the Canadian minister of energy, ever the faithful lap-dog of the international nuclear community, wrote me the other day that the

May 6, 1992
consequences of Chernobyl were "not as serious as many people have been lead to believe".
Canada and other nations need to put aside their fear of exposing the truth about this event and come quickly to the aid of Ukraine in dealing with this issue.
Help with the sarcophagus is needed, help with unbiased studies and help to ensure that other similar reactors in Ukraine, Lithuania and elsewhere do not melt down. That help is needed now, before any more damage is done to planet earth in the name of this particular energy option.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate our women's hockey team on its outstanding performance at the world women's hockey championships in Tampere, Finland.
On April 26, during an exciting final game, Canada's women's team shut out the U.S. 8 to 0. Thanks to this major victory, Canada now has the only team so far to hold the women's hockey world championship title. We are looking forward to seeing women's hockey become part of the Winter Olympic Games and hope that will be the case by 1998. Meanwhile, I am sure that all members present and all Canadians will wish to join me in applauding this outstanding achievement by all members of the Canadian team and their coaches, and in wishing them good luck at the next championship games.

Pitch-In Week 92 is taking place this week in several provinces across Canada.
Last year it involved over two million volunteers. It is an extremely thrifty and effective public initiative. For example, for every dollar spent on organizing the national program, $141 was contributed by volunteers, the media and local governments.
The objectives of the Pitch-In Week program are to involve Canadians in environmental enhancement activities; to clean up litter while encouraging voluntary action as a means of resolving the littering problem; and to encourage the reduction, re-use and recycling of waste.
Last year, over 7,800 projects undertaken by over two million Canadians in over 1,100 communities across Canada donated labour totalling over $72 million.
I urge all Canadians to support this program in order to help make active environmentalism a reality for all Canadians.
In my community there is a similar program. Take Pride Winnipeg is encouraging all residents to get a grip on litter. I join Laurie Hunter and all of the participants in helping to try to make Canada a cleaner place for all of us and all of our children.

Mr. Speaker, for the past two nights the streets of downtown Toronto have been the scene of intolerable violence and looting.
On Sunday I watched in disbelief as an organized peaceful demonstration against racism turned violent and Toronto began to look like south central L.A.
Constituents have called me saying they will continue to feel safe only if the police continue to have the power to stop all violence and crimes. I support the efforts of the Metropolitan Toronto Police in quelling the violence and in attempting to keep Toronto safe for everyone.
I also support calls to put an end to systemic discrimination that continues to raise its ugly head in Canada and the United States.

Mr. Speaker, Raymond Blain, municipal counsellor for Saint-Jacques in Montreal, died yesterday. Mr. Blain was dedicated to improving the lives of his constituents, and he was also a friend. Mr. Blain represented a disadvantaged section of Montreal. Saint-Jacques also includes the Gay Village, and Mr. Blain, who was a
May 6, 1992

member of this community, was instrumental in bringing the gay community and the general population of Montreal closer together.
Raymond Blain was one of the first gay politicians to come out of the closet. In doing so he helped to make the entire community aware of this reality and brought hope to the entire gay community. He leaves us with a message of faith in the future, a future that he wished to see based on non-violence, sharing and non-discrimination. Raymond Blain, thank you!

Mr. Speaker, Canadians do not perceive themselves as belonging to a racist society. On the contrary, we want respect and equal opportunities for all. However, some members of our society feel left out and have the impression they have been treated unfairly. Very often they are right. We must try and break down the social and economic barriers that inevitably lead to despair, aggressive behaviour, and sometimes even riots.
More than ever before we must pool our resources to find new ways to cope with new realities. We must be more willing to listen to what people have to say and more sensitive to the many signals people are sending us.
Mr. Speaker, racism is everybody's business. It is up to each and every one of us to stop racism. The government has shown it is prepared to do its share. It cannot do this in a vacuum. It needs every one of us. Canadians should be able to treat human values as they should be treated, with great respect, and to do so they must fully understand their significance.

[Editor's Note: Member spoke in Inuktitut.]
Mr. Speaker, I have just returned from my constituency of Nunatsiaq where on Monday, residents voted overwhelmingly in favour of a boundary for a new
territory in the eastern Arctic. My constituents have reaffirmed decisively their desire, commitment and readiness to have their own government.
We are now firmly on our way toward the establishment of Nunavut in 1999.1 want to congratulate all those who worked so hard and for so long to achieve this goal.
I want to thank all the people of the Northwest Territories who supported our aspirations. We are grateful for their understanding and endorsement.
The people of both the eastern and western Arctic can look forward to governments which are closer to them and more responsive to their needs.
History was made on Monday. A giant step was taken in the building and strengthening of this nation. We must all work together now to ensure a smooth transition to Nunavut.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this week Canadians are celebrating National Forest Week in recognition of our country's greatest natural resource.
I come from a province where forestry contributes immensely to our economic and social well-being. Each year nearly $1 billion is injected into the Nova Scotian economy for the manufacture of forest products. Some 21,000 people are directly and indirectly employed by the industry, 4,000 of them in my South Shore riding.
Nova Scotia provides 50 per cent of Canada's exports of Christmas trees and indeed the finest Christmas trees in the world they are.
On behalf of all Nova Scotians, I encourage all members and all Canadians to participate in National Forest Week activities planned throughout the week in communities across the land.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday was parliamentary day for the International Association of Fire-fighters.

May 6, 1992
Today, I would still like to point out the excellent work done by fire-fighters and more particularly to commend the fire-fighters in Saint-Laurent. I also believe that the Association's requests must be considered and it is important as well to recognize their professionalism.
I want to congratulate the fire-fighters in my riding on being one of the first groups to receive the "code 2" designation.

I would like to take the opportunity to express my gratitude to the fire-fighters of my riding who have, for many years now, maintained a code 2 rating and to compliment these dedicated men for their community involvement in Saint-Laurent.

Mr. Speaker, the economic recovery is fragile, but it is under way and that is good.
Interest rates are low, and that is good. People are willing to invest right now, and that is good. The federal government in its last budget introduced measures to help small business financing, and that is good.
What is not good is the fact that economic expansion right now is being threatened by a lack of credit. The big banks are restricting credit, calling in loans, asking for unreasonable collateral and hurting small business.
At a time when the bankers in this countiy have made record profits, surely the banks can afford to loosen up to help small businesses and help farmers in this country. These people are asking for no more than the Reich-manns did, which the Reichmanns got, and at considerably less risk to the economy.

Mr. Speaker, yet again I find I must rise in this House to condemn the government and the Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development for its failure to address the chronic underfunding of schools on reserves.
This afternoon the Chief of the Red Sucker Lake Indian Band will announce that his community school will be closed due to serious building code and health and safety violations. The deplorable condition of the school at Red Sucker Lake is known by the Department of Indian Affairs. The department's own report cited serious problems requiring immediate action including rotting floor beams, the need to replace inadequate plumbing, the need to replace an antiquated chlorination system that produces toxic fumes, the need to excavate the foundation and remove contaminated soil that produces fumes that seep into the main building.
I call upon the minister of Indian affairs to commit the necessary funds to begin the process of new school construction in Red Sucker Lake as proposed by his predecessor in the fall of 1987.
Indian Affairs itself has identified a number of schools with very serious building code violations like Red Sucker Lake school. It is time to clean up and improve these schools.

Mr. Speaker, the stay in school initiative is designed to reduce Canada's high school drop-out rate.
It is an excellent program that has worked well in my riding. Stay in school began in Cumberland County in February 1991 with the federal government kick-starting the program.
The community then jumped in to establish partnerships. The partners are teachers, parents, and employers who work together to come up with creative projects that will keep our youth interested and in school.
One example of a very successful project is the "Second Chance" program in Springhill. It actually brings kids back to school by involving them in a semester program as a way of completing their classes.
There are over 40 projects in my riding that are successful under the stay in school initiative and it is working well.
May 6, 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask a question of the Prime Minister.
The large cities of Canada are in big trouble because of unemployment, food banks, violent crime, drugs, homeless people. Yesterday this government was sent an SOS. Will the Prime Minister meet right away with the mayors of the big cities of Canada to address these very urgent problems?

Mr. Speaker, I will be happy to meet with anyone at any time if it might be helpful in dealing with a given problem.
Sure, we have social difficulties in some of our big cities but I would be disinclined to describe it in the same terms of imminent calamity that my friend uses.
The Conference Board reported this morning, for example, that business confidence is up to its highest level in two years. The economic turnaround continues. So there will be both economic and social improvements.
While we have serious difficulties that we have to deal with in some of the major cities, I do not believe there is that kind of crisis to warrant the terms that some members of the House use to describe a difficult situation.
Sure, I would be happy to meet with whomever at any point in time if that would be helpful and I would happy to entertain as well any reasonable and direct suggestions from members of the House on this or any other subject.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if the Prime Minister is prepared to meet with the mayors, they will be very pleased to have the opportunity to hold discussions with the Prime Minister, because I do not think that this government has paid much attention to the mayors of our big cities for several years. Not more than a few months ago, they again asked for help from the governments. They are ready to launch job-creation programs immediately and to pay a third of the cost, but the Minister of Finance stubbornly refuses to listen to them.
Oral Questions
The important thing for the cities is to restore social peace and give people some hope. Will the Prime Minister instruct his finance minister accordingly?

Mr. Speaker, I received no request from the mayors of Toronto, Montreal or Vancouver for a meeting such as the Leader of the Opposition mentioned.
The Minister of Finance and other ministers regularly meet with officials of the large cities to discuss bilateral problems and new possibilities. The Government of Canada, together with the provinces, has programs that make life easier for Canadian municipalities. Of course we can improve them, but it will take specific suggestions to do so.
Speaking of big cities, the other day the Leader of the Opposition went to Montreal and met the mayor of Montreal. On Sunday, his office announced that he would make an important speech on economic and social problems. Instead, he delivered a trite speech in Montreal, while his office in Ottawa released a much more detailed presentation.
Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition could tell us whether the Montreal speech or the text released in Ottawa should take precedence.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in Montreal I spoke of the problems this country is facing because of the economic policies of this government which has created the mess we are in today.
I spoke of high unemployment, misery in the street. People cannot find housing. There are 15,000 homeless people in Montreal. I spoke of the problems of the people in Montreal. I said to these people of Montreal and the rest of Canada that what we need in Canada is a government that cares for the people, and that day is coming soon. When the Prime Minister calls an election, we will solve these problems.

Mr. Speaker, that is precisely it. The Leader of the Opposition said he went to Montreal. Indeed he did go to Montreal. The problem with Montreal is that he left his speech in Ottawa. The major speech he was to have delivered Sunday in Montreal he did not deliver. The office in Ottawa put out a speech. I must say the speech

May 6, 1992
Oral Questions
the leader did not deliver in Ottawa was much better than the one he did in Montreal.
Apart from the platitudes that came out of him in Montreal, there was not a single solitary suggestion as to what might be done, except to break the bank with borrowed money and that we will not do. We are working to lower interest rates. We are lowering interest rates. We are increasing economic growth. We are attracting greater foreign investment. This is going to create more jobs.
If my hon. friend has another idea or a better idea, please tell the House of Commons now.

Mr. Speaker, in the absence of the Minister of National Health and Welfare, my question is for the Prime Minister.
It has to do with the fact that the federal government's support for community-based drug outreach and rehabilitation programs is terribly inadequate. Street and community workers want to meet with the government, address the root causes of drug use, discuss drug education strategies, and receive commitments for long-term rehabilitation programs. When will the Prime Minister announce an adequate funding policy for community based programs that would prevent drug use, anticipate solutions, and offer long-term rehabilitation?

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, with regard to drug abuse and substance abuse, the minister announced four weeks ago another $270 million going into the treatment of drugs. We are working with our provincial colleagues, with the Departments of National Health and Welfare, in regard to co-ordinating our efforts along with the municipalities so that we can get a better handle and treat the youth with regard to drug abuse.

Mr. Speaker, does the parliamentary secretary realize that despite this influx of money, drug trafficking and use in our cities is on the rise? What will the parliament secretary and the government do to ensure that the money announced last
March will reach community based drug prevention and rehabilitation agencies instead of being used for glitzy campaigns and fancy conferences?

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, it is not for glitzy campaigns and fancy conferences. We are here to treat this very devastating problem we have and it has to do with substance abuse. With regard to the drug trafficking area, you have heard from the Solicitor General on how he is approaching that. As I said, the $270 million that was announced some weeks ago is maybe just a beginning, but indeed we are working with all the agencies across the country to help alleviate this problem.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. It seems increasingly clear that the government will proceed with enabling legislation on a referendum and possibly with a referendum. I know that the Prime Minister is well aware, as is everyone else in this House, that such an issue requires careful ground work and a well thought out plan and answers to important questions.
Therefore, I would ask the Prime Minister if the enabling legislation that he is proposing will determine what will constitute a majority in a vote, if it will also determine how minority interests will be guaranteed and what the process will be for determining the question of a referendum.
Mr. Speaker, I understand that the House leader has begun consultations with the House leaders of the main political parties. Am I wrong on that, Harvie?

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: No. Yes.
Oh, I see.
Give him time.
Can I help?

Forgive me. It was not a consultation. It was a conversation that the House leader had with both other House leaders, precisely on some of the questions that my hon. friend raises, or conversations or consultations that will no doubt lead to that.
May 6, 1992

The government is considering the nature of the legislation and in the process of doing this is taking into account some of the questions my hon. friend raises. As soon as we can, when we have the outlines of what might be acceptable, I know that the House leader will meet with the House leaders of the other parties to get the benefit of their views and criticisms and then bring it forward for consideration by the House.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary for the Prime Minister. It is true that this party has been advised that enabling legislation will be brought forward, but not in terms of the questions that I have raised.
Quite separate from House leaders discussions, I am interested again in asking the Prime Minister what he has thought out as the plan in terms of these questions. Has he considered such issues as what the length of a campaign would be around a referendum, what kind of funding would be available, whether there would be spending limits or third party advertising? These are questions quite separate from that of the House leaders discussions. We have been advised there will be enabling legislation, but I am assuming that the government has thought this out well and has a plan.
My questions are simply directed to the Prime Minister and asking for his responses to these questions.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in conversations with House leaders and whips and deputy House leaders yesterday of the three parties, I indicated to those present that the question for example of spending limits, public assistance and so on are tied into what is permissible under the charter of rights in terms of restrictions and that is something that needs to be looked at. As I indicated, we would be discussing this further with the opposition after we have the benefit of legal advice and so on.
Those kinds of questions, important though they are, are details that I had indicated we would be discussing. In terms of the length of a campaign, the minimum length is dictated by the Chief Electoral Officer in terms of the tasks that we would require of him in the legislation. To some extent, that depends on the details
Oral Questions
in the legislation, but it is also the fact of how long it takes him to enumerate and establish things. That is a practical detail which we can get from the Chief Electoral Officer when we present him with our proposals.

Mr. Speaker, again for the Prime Minister. Obviously, these are all important questions but if enabling legislation is going to be put before the House next week, as the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs has suggested, surely the government has some responses.

Mr. Speaker, I wish to ask the Prime Minister a supplementary question. The Prime Minister knows very well that even holding a referendum does not allow him to amend the Constitution without the agreement of at least seven provinces that have 50 per cent of the population. Therefore it is very important for the provincial and territorial governments, as well as native people, to be involved in formulating the question that the government may ask in a referendum.
Will the Prime Minister involve them in formulating a question and how will he do so?

First and foremost, Mr. Speaker, we hope to solve this problem in the negotiations now under way in Saint John, New Brunswick with Mr. Clark and his provincial colleagues.
So if a settlement is reached within a few weeks, even better. At that time, if an agreement is reached or the provinces give us an indication of their intention to proceed, either unanimously or on a 7-50 basis, together as a party, we will make a judgment on the basic document.
If there is no agreement, we will have to break the deadlock somehow and a referendum is a legitimate way to do so. But before going ahead with a referendum or passing a bill, we will of course seek the consent and approval of the opposition parties, as well as the co-operation and concurrence of the leaders of the two other major federalist parties in this House.

Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, recently there have been indications that the negotiators of a North American free trade agreement are completing the text.
I would ask the minister whether he could confirm these rumours. Will he explain what adjustment assistance programs this government plans to introduce to help prepare Canadians for a more open North American free trade area?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as I have indicated in questions that have been put to me by the media, last week was a good week in the negotiations. A number of things were moved on the negotiating front. Some of them were important as far as Canadian interests are concerned.
I have been asked whether an agreement is imminent. I have said that was not the case, that we still had some major issues to resolve. This may take us a few more weeks as yet.
On the question of adjustment, my hon. friend is aware of the significant increases that have been brought in to increase training for people who are between jobs or people who are looking for a job change. That is important whether it is in relation to a free trade agreement or whether it is in response to the ongoing change that is under way in the economy today.

Mr. Speaker, the minister knows full well that if the challenges posed by a North American free trade agreement are the same as those posed by economic globalization then Canadians need creative adjustment assistance programs now, free trade agreement or not.
When will the government introduce a far-reaching program of adjustment assistance as a prerequisite of freer trade, as was promised repeatedly four years ago in the last election?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TYade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my friend has pointed out that there is a requirement for adjustment programs just in response to
the significant amount of change that is going on in the global economy today. The increase in that change resulting from a North American free trade agreement is not likely to be that great because of the significance of trade with Mexico relative to the over-all size of our trade. It is less than 1 per cent.
My hon. friend is very much aware that since the free trade agreement came in we have had the report of the de Grandpre committee. We have responded to that by increasing the amount of training. We have responded with the Canadian Labour Force Development Board which brings business and labour together in order to advise the government on what training programs should be made.
I might observe that when this legislation to increase the amount of training in the unemployment insurance budget was brought into the House, his colleagues here and in the Senate held up that legislation for over a year. It was for that reason that we were delayed in bringing these important adjustment programs on stream.
Thankfully they are on stream because of the persistence of this government in bringing about the adjustment programs that are necessary.

Mr. Speaker, since its initial share offering last June, Petro-Cana-da's shares have fallen from $13 to about $8. Another 400 to 500 lay-offs were announced at the stormy first annual meeting yesterday in Calgary.
Is the minister of energy or the acting minister of energy pleased with Petro-Canada's performance to date? Why does the company, still 80 per cent owned by the Government of Canada, have funds for continued drilling in Myanmar but seemingly not for Syncrude, for Hibernia or for more oil and gas exploration throughout western Canada?

speakeroldname: Mr. John A. MacDougall (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member has brought forward many questions. I think it is most important to remember that Petro-Cana-da today is much like a lot of the other oil companies. It is going through a very difficult time with a downturn both on the energy side of it and also on the consumer
May 6, 1992

side of it, with consumers today being much more knowledgeable in the use of gas and not using the gas they normally used years before.
We have to recognize that our industries are in a very difficult way. Petro-Canada has to downsize in order to keep a market available for itself. I think that is what it has done.
It is very unfortunate employees have to lose their jobs; but in a sector that is going through difficult times in order to stay financially viable they did not have any other choice.

Mr. Speaker, about 60,000 people have lost their jobs in the oil and gas sector in western Canada.
The Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs or the acting minister has presumably already investigated whether Petro-Canada and its underwriters did a due diligence prospectus before the shares were offered to the public last year. What can he tell us about that study today? Can Canadians rely on a government owned company and its underwriters to provide reasonable due diligence before the Canadian public is invited to buy shares, not afterward?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:

Mr. Speaker, as the Governments of Canada, the United States and Mexico move rapidly toward a new free trade agreement between those three countries, advertisements begin to appear in Canadian newspapers relative to staking one's claim in the new free trade territory, put in by the Central Power and Light Company of south Texas.
On phoning this light company, the sponsors of the ad in The Globe and Mail, we spoke to Mr. Amando Soto, manager of economic development. He informed us that:
We can provide any company who locales here with a very low cost of doing business-Communities offer land, through giveaways or favourable lease, and tax abatements. Texas offers training packages, and if you're locating in an "enterprise zone" you're eligible for tax rebates.
Oral Questions
Does the minister not agree that this advertising and the positions it supports are a violation of the so-called level playing field between Canada and the United States?

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I must say I hesitate to take at face value what my hon. friend is quoting others to say because I think it was some three weeks ago he promised the House that he was going to table a letter from some unnamed senator in Mexico. with the city, county and school districts officials and work out a deal.

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology

My hon. friend is asking a question about the definition of subsidy. He knows perfectly well that matter has been referred to the GATT talks. It is under the GATT talks the matter will hopefully be resolved.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of the Environment. This week, long standing suspicions were confirmed that vast quantities of radioactive waste had been dumped in Russian Arctic waters.
What steps has the government taken to ensure that these materials will be neutralized or recovered before they contaminate Canadian Arctic waters? Furthermore, has the government received assurances from Russia that from now on no more radioactive waste will be dumped in their Arctic waters?

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean J. Charest (Minister of the Environment):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we received the same information that the hon. member obtained via the media, namely that the government of the Soviet Union had supposedly dumped toxic radioactive waste. We will check this information. The hon. member also mentioned obtaining certain
assurances from the government in question. We will try, if indeed it is possible, to find out exactly what happened.
The hon. member must realize that today, in what used to be the Soviet Union, it is not always easy to know exactly what happened. Furthermore, I would like to point out that we have an Arctic environmental strategy with a budget of $100 million, as part of Canada's green plan. The purpose of this strategy is to conduct research on the various substances we find in our environment and thus put us in a better position to detect the presence of such substances in Canada's environment.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the same minister.
The threat to Canada posed by the massive dumping of radioactive Russian waste into the Arctic is very serious. What is equally serious, however, is the fact that this government has compromised Canada's ability to react.
The cancellation of a previously announced series of monitoring initiatives and the failure to replace the polar continental shelf project are simply examples of this. Mr. Speaker, my debate was interrupted yesterday in the House for other House business. I should recap very briefly the items in relation to Bill C-71, an act to amend the Criminal Records Act which we were debating yesterday.
The bill itself provides a band-aid solution to two or three measures that needed addressing.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I would like to bring to the attention to the hon. member that he has 10 minutes remaining in the debate plus 10 minutes for questions and comments.

To recap, there are three areas that the bill intended and does address.
First is the speeding up of processing by applicants for the purging of their criminal records.
Second, it changes a couple of rules dealing with criminal records procedure to enhance the effectiveness of the legislation.

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
Third, it addresses the accumulating problem of there being in the bill conditional and absolute discharges which have to be pardoned.
As I said the other day, the discharges under the Criminal Code were intended to produce no criminal record.
The Criminal Records Act now says that even though you have been discharged, you will be deemed to have a criminal record. Now these amendments will remove that and provide for an automatic disposition of the record of the discharge. That is a good thing.
However, these amendments do not disguise some rather significant flaws in relation to the statute itself. As I stand here, I have to say that I do not know why the government chose to address this bill by means of band-aids. It is not a complicated bill. I do not know why it did not go back and reconstruct the statute.
As I have said and will point out again, in a bill where the title is the Criminal Records Act, the term criminal record is not even defined in the statute. The act does not even attempt to manage criminal records in any capacity whatsoever. In fact, the bill does not set out to deal with criminal records; it sets out to deal with records of conviction. That is an important difference.
The mechanism used in the act is that of a pardon. The bill does not even define what a pardon is.
Administratively, judicial officials across the country probably do not have a very good fix on what this statute is trying to accomplish.
To pick up where I left off, I wanted to give an example of one of the problems that exists with this statute that the bill does not address.
If an individual has a criminal record, and if the record of conviction is conveyed to the Canadian Police Record Information System managed by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police-we call that CPIC-then CPIC has a notation of the record of conviction.
CPIC also has a lot of other information that we generally characterize as criminal records. If it gets there, and most do but not all do, it sits on the CPIC system as a notation of a record of conviction.
Often the records are exchanged with other law enforcement agencies. The United States law enforcement agencies exchange records with us. There are some 100 U.S. agencies that have power of arrest.
When the record is exchanged, it gets on the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service record system or the FBI, the border patrol, or some other system. Once it is there, our mechanisms for getting rid of criminal records do not even attempt to get rid of the notation of the record in the U.S. systems.
In addition to that, criminal records and records of conviction still exist in the Canadian system in municipal police offices, provincial police offices, court houses all across the country, and other government agencies. This statute does not even attempt to get rid of them.
In the definition of pardon, the mechanism that the statute purports to use is as follows: "After your application is approved, you shall have a pardon". This is what happens when there is this undefined pardon. The pardon will be evidence of good conduct. It is evidence that the pardon issued should no longer reflect adversely on the applicant's character. That is a good wish in the statute and not much more than that. It removes any disqualification that the person has by virtue of any act of or under Parliament.
What about all of the other legislation in this country, provincial and municipal? All of those statutes may well and do contain disabilities as the result of a record of conviction. This act does not address those.
In the end, although the act tries to clean up the record, whether it is a criminal record or record of conviction, it does not do either. It does not deal with it. These records still exist randomly, messily in a disorganized fashion. Even though we have one Criminal Code and even though there is one record of conviction in the code, those records continue to exist all across the country. Therefore, this amendment to the statute does not really deal with the real problems of the statute. I wish that it did and hope that the legislative committee which will deal with it-I believe it will be the justice committee sitting as a legislative committee-can begin to address those problems.
May 6, 1992

If it cannot it is fair to say that a future government will, whoever that government may be. I would like to think that members on this side of the House would like a chance to address that challenge.
This is a circumstance where the government has addressed a real need. That I concede. It has speeded up the processing but it has not addressed the real deficiencies contained in the Criminal Records Act. It delivers a lot less to the citizen than it purports to do in the amendments. That is unfortunately so often the case with many of the amendments made in the judicial area by this government over the last few months.
However, cosmetic as some of them may be, as superficial or as much of a band-aid as they are, they do attempt to deal with the needs.
We must deal with the records of convictions and criminal records in all of the provincial capitals, all of the provincial and municipal police forces. That has not been done. We must deal with the records of conviction and criminal records exchanged with other countries, including the U.S.A. That has not been done in the statute and is not intended to be done by the amendment. Also, we must deal with all of those records which should have been placed in CPIC and should have been centralized but never were because of flaws in the current reporting and recording system in criminal records.
The suggestion that the Criminal Records Act deals with criminal records is false. It does not have anything to do with criminal records. The whole issue of criminal records is sitting out there as a federal jurisdiction, unmanaged, and basically unregulated. The information system that is supposed to be there is not.
I congratulate the RCMP on doing what it can. The CPIC system does serve a function. However I think we can make it better.
Having said that, I look forward to being able to take the bill up at committee and maybe there we can make some badly needed improvements to the statute.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I intend to be very brief in my remarks on this important bill. I know that the hon. Minister for International Trade and various other titles will want to participate in the debate himself, because I am sure that the subject of pardons is one that is very near to his heart.
It is clearly an important issue in my area. There have been numerous pardons with which I dealt in providing assistance for people making these applications since my election in 1988.1 do not suppose that is surprising, given the number of penal reform institutions in the Kingston area. Some of the persons residing in those institutions have settled in the Kingston area, and after the requisite period of time they have made application on occasion for pardons.
I listened with great interest to the speech of the Solicitor General the other day when he introduced this bill. He spoke of the serious backlog and the problems with respect to pardons. I suggested to him during his speech that part of the problem was exacerbated by government cutbacks instituted by the current Minister of Industry, Science and Technology when he was Minister of Finance. I suspect that these Draconian cutbacks have increased the problems for those applying for pardons. Of course, the minister denied that. He may be right. However, what he did say, and I agree with him, is that he has made every effort to assist members of Parliament when they apply for help with a pardon application and where it is required on a timely basis.
I agree that he has been helpful in that regard and I acknowledge that assistance.
These pardons are very important to the individuals who require them. The public is perhaps unaware of the importance. Many members of the public who wish to travel to the United States are unable to enter that country because of a past criminal conviction, often of a very minor nature. Obtaining the pardon in advance solves the problem at the U.S. border and the individual is able to enter without further obstruction or difficulty.
Accordingly, the question of obtaining pardons is often vital. It is also important in terms of certain job opportunities for members of the public. They may apply to do a

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
job requiring certain security clearances and a criminal record is an absolute bar to their application.
While we may say that this bill seems relatively unimportant to many people who have not been involved with the law, for those who have it represents a significant opportunity to make up for past wrongs, get on with life, and to allow new opportunities to be opened to them.
For that reason I am pleased that the minister has seen fit to do something to speed up the process. As indicated by my very learned colleague from Scarborough-Rouge River, we support the principle of this bill and are pleased to do so. We will certainly review the provisions of the bill very carefully when it is referred to a committee of this House.
I hope that I will have some say at the committee stage on this particular bill, though I doubt that I will be a member of the committee. I will certainly watch the proceedings of the committee with great care. I know that the hon. member for Sault Ste. Marie would be glad if I was there. I suspect that perhaps he will be his party's representative on the committee.
No, I am not.

He says he is not. I hope that he will watch the progress of this bill very carefully, as I will. I am sure that, coming from a community of similar size, he shares the interest that all hon. members have in seeing that this kind of legislation is enacted promptly and in ensuring that it serves the best interests of those who need these pardons.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to speak on Bill C-71.1 am perhaps the first non-legal individual to speak to it. I am probably on shaky ground because I do not have any legal expertise whatsoever, and perhaps I am not as concerned with the definition of pardon et cetera as some of the previous speakers have been.
I am hopefully going to approach Bill C-71 from a very pragmatic point of view as it impacts upon many Canadians, 25,000 in 1990. It has impacted upon approximately 20 to 25 of my constituents who have asked me and my staff to intervene on their behalf to expedite the pardon process, which I am happy to do.
As there is a 25,000 backlog of individuals looking for pardons we welcome the facilitating of this process. We understand that more resources in terms of moneys and staff are being given so that the process can be expedited, and we applaud that process.
When the accumulated backlog has increased from 7,000 to 25,000 it is obvious that the demand for expediting the process should have been addressed previously.
The people who have approached me in my office have struck me as being veiy sincere. They are people who are-I do not want to use the word rehabilitated -good, honest citizens who have paid their dues to the system. They are saying: "I want out of this now, I want to get rid of this stigma". It is a stigma. I have received letters from constituents and it is ironic that many of them are applying for work in law enforcement. In fact more often than not they are in some sort of social work, security, or law enforcement position.
It does indicate that these people are indeed concerned and oftentimes have been unaware that the record has stuck with them over a period, in some cases, of eight, 10,12, or 15 years. It is a shame that being guilty of a drunk driving charge 15 years earlier may prohibit someone from proceeding to a chosen line of work.
The concept of streamlining from 18 months down to six months is very appealing. We laud that goal. However, if there is a three or five-year period, it does not seem right that after that period applicants will still have to wait probably a minimum of six months before they are granted a pardon.
If I may draw an analogy from my previous career in school, it is like giving a detention to young people and keeping them after school for the next week. The term is served, but afterwards it is discussed whether to continue the term or not.
Once someone has paid his or her dues or served his or her time, good time with good behaviour, he or she should be excused immediately.
We laud the fact that the 18-month time period is being reduced to six months, but certainly the improvement could be immediate. If we can reduce it from 18 months to six months it begs the question as to why it cannot be reduced to three months or two months, the
May 6, 1992

faster the better. The people looking for these pardons are always in untenable situations in which the pardon is absolutely essential.
I salute the minister for his help. My experience is that it is important to have someone at an MP's desk so that if a constituent calls a member, he or she can intervene. However, after seeing the backlog of 25,000 I am somewhat reticent to ask that the minister or staff intervene when I know that the pile is so high.
I represent a border community which faces the implications of not harmonizing with the United States, or at least attempting to harmonize. If someone has committed any sort of offence in the United States and comes back to Canada and it appears on the computer at the border no matter what is done to attempt to get a waiver from U.S. immigration, or if he or she would like a pardon, it is nigh on impossible to get a pardon from the system in the United States. I speak from a great deal of experience.
The immigration office in Detroit that fields these concerns from constituents or members of Parliament totally ignores them. The people in U.S. immigration suggest that this is the lowest on its priority list. Usually Canadian pardons are at the bottom of the list and the process can go on and on. Actually 18 months in Canada is certainly praiseworthy when compared to the United States.
Were it not for the good offices of Congressman Davis from Michigan I do not know if we would ever get any solutions for Canadians who had committed some offence in the United States.
It begs that there be some international agreement. If we can achieve free trade surely to God we can achieve some sort of agreement on criminal records.
We believe that if you serve your time you should be out of the system as soon as possible. At the same time some say it is a band-aid approach. I do not have the expertise to even suggest it is a band-aid approach but it is an improvement that is required and desired so we will not stand in the way.
The member for Brant has told me we are eager to get this bill to committee. We will take a look at the fine print and not stand in the way of the bill.
