speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to begin debate at third reading of Bill C-53.
First I would like to express my gratitude to the members of the committee, particularly the members of the opposition, who helped to facilitate the passage of this legislation. I think it is accurate to say that all members of the House want to see this bill passed.
We may not all agree on the details of the provisions but we do agree on the nature of the bill, on the need for this kind of legislation to be passed, in order to provide an effective measure to deal with aggression anywhere in the world and to enable us as a country to combine with other nations of the world through multilateral organizations and have combined forces to deal with despotism and aggression wherever it is in the world when we are called upon to do so.
I would like to thank those who appeared before the committee as witnesses to give expert testimony out of their own concerns and sometimes out of their own experiences to explain to us the kind of provisions and the kind of exigencies we are dealing with.
I speak specifically of groups such as humanitarian organizations, the Mennonite Central Committee, or the doctor who appeared before us or groups such as the bankers association, those who were a coalition opposed to the actions during the gulf war.
We received a whole spectrum of points of view, largely as a result of their experience in the gulf war,

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
although in the case of the MCC it had to do with their experiences in Cambodia. They pointed out that working with the Canadian government gave them greater latitude in their charitable work in countries where there was aggression than if they were working, for example, under the aegis of the American government.
They spoke regarding their concerns about the effect of this legislation would have in their arenas. It may be that some of these witnesses feel that the amendments and the legislation do not accommodate their concerns.
I would like to point out to the House that the bill we are passing today, hopefully, is what we call framework legislation. It is designed to provide a structure to give the government of the day the mechanisms to deal with the aggression that we are talking about in the confines of this bill.
Framework legislation is, by its very nature, flexible. For example, clause 4 gives the kind of latitude to the government to allow humanitarian organizations at the discretion of the government and at the discretion of the conditions that exist at the time.
It gives the government the kind of latitude, for example, sometimes to allow those humanitarian organizations to do the very thing that they seek to do. What we have to be careful of, as I pointed out yesterday, is that the humanitarian value systems that we espouse and enjoy in Canada are not abused by the despots, by the naked aggression in other countries.
It was our experience as a nation that when the original United Nations resolutions were passed, they did allow for exceptions for humanitarian food aid or medical aid to be transmitted to the Iraqi civilians. It soon became necessary, however, to restrict those resolutions in such a way that it narrowed down the opportunity to do that kind of humanitarian work.
The tragedy is that the very subject that we are dealing with makes it difficult to carry on humanitarian work. I pointed out in committee that when we were dealing with sanctions for South Africa, a lot of the arguments that came to us in the House of Commons against the use of sanctions centred around the fact that the impoverished, the disadvantaged, the unprotected would suffer the most.
Therefore, the unemployed, the blacks living in poor regions, would be the very ones to suffer when they were the ones who we wanted to emancipate. I recall very clearly at the time that Bishop TUtu said: "That is absolutely true, but that is the price we have to pay in order to put pressure on the government to change the system so that ultimately we can enjoy the kind of freedom and human rights that all of us are seeking".
I suppose that is true in every situation where sanctions are employed. As I said yesterday, the most horrible experience is war. The next most horrible experience is the imposition of sanctions. It will be the innocent who suffer.
I say to the humanitarian organizations that the specific exceptions they are asking for are, in effect, included in the bill because it is framework legislation. If we were to enumerate the exceptions, we would fragment the nature of framework legislation and thereby constrict the very flexibility we want in this legislation.
The second point that is of interest to people, to members of the House and others is the role of Parliament at times such as this. I know that there are members who would like to see mechanisms in the legislation which call for the mandatory recall of Parliament within a certain number of days. There is something attractive about that, because all of us in this House believe in the widest public debate of matters of national and international interest and concern.
However, as I pointed out yesterday, there are standing orders already which enable us to do many of the things that the opposition has in mind. I guess at the very bottom of it-and I speak for myself now, I am not speaking on behalf of the government when I say this-there are times when we have to choose the way of doing things between what would essentially result in an American kind of congressional system and a parliamentary system, which is the heritage we enjoy in this Chamber.
We operate under a system of responsible and accountable government with an executive branch that is responsible to the people and pays the political price if it ignores them.
Recall of Parliament is an executive responsibility that is part of the parliamentary system here and in other Parliaments of the world. If an executive of the parliamentary system ignores the wishes of the people he will pay the political price.
May 6, 1992

In addition to that, there are all of the other parliamentary precedents and standing orders which allow for full debate of issues such as this. There are opposition days, standing orders and all of the other devices that are at the disposal of members of Parliament. The committees can be recalled for full accounting.
I want to assure the public that is watching and members of the House that this is a bill which I think many of us would like to have seen implemented at the time of the gulf war. Many of us would have liked to have seen it implemented during the time of the sanctions on South Africa and I suppose in the case of Rhodesia.
I think the public will welcome this legislation. While the opposition may wish that some of the amendments they put forward had been accepted, I want to assure them and the public at large that the bill we are dealing with today will meet the goals they have in mind, even though some of the technical details do not espouse some of the amendments they put forward.
I want to thank again the members for their co-operation in the facilitation of this legislation and the ability that this will give Parliament on behalf of the Canadian people to deal with the need to co-operate with other countries and multilateral organizations in bringing pressure to bear on despotism wherever it exists in the world.

Mr. Speaker, I too want to add some concluding comments on this bill at third reading and to express a general approval of the bill. It is necessary for Canada to pull together in one statute the powers and responsibilities of the government to act in one of the most crucial and important decisions that any political system has to make and that is to undertake reaction or responses to acts of aggression internationally or to threats of peace and security. We have taken that position from the outset.
However, I use this third reading also to express great regret at what this bill could have been and what it has in fact turned out to be.
There was an opportunity at the outset for this to be more than just a technical bill. It could have also been an opportunity for the Government of Canada to set forward some principles and policies about how we
Government Orders
would respond to the changes going on in the world and how we would attempt to use these powers in a different kind of way than what we saw happen during the gulf war when the drums of chauvinism, emotion and nationalism were at the height and when the whole hysteria and fever of war took over and made it a black and white situation.
Here was the chance to set out how a government in a modem day has to modulate and be carefully composed in its way of approaching these difficult war and peace type decisions. Unfortunately, at the second reading of this bill there was none of that from the minister and we have received none of that since then.
There is an interesting phrase that the parliamentary secretary used. It is now called framework legislation. That is a euphemism. I suppose one thing we could say about the parliamentary secretary is that he will make the world safe for euphemisms. It is simply another word for entrenching executive power and making it as immune as possible from democratic accountability and responsibility. Framework legislation is a way of saying: Let the officials and the minister decide without having to meet the test of public judgment and public accountability on an ongoing basis.
It is the old style of governing. It is the style of governing that has made so many Canadians angry or mad about what is going on. They want more from their govemments. They want more from their Parliament. They do not want a group of people in back rooms making decisions, especially life and death decisions. This is not deciding whether we are going to raise the tax on purple gasoline by a few cents. This is talking about the Government of Canada taking unto itself enormous powers to control public and private life and activity. When we take away all the frills, we still come down to the basic judgment that will be taken behind a closed door by a minister and the cabinet.
That has to be a source of major regret. Here was a chance to step forward, to show Canadians that we were prepared in parliamentary terms not simply to hand over immense powers to bureaucracies and the executive

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
power of government, but to leaven it with some sense of more openness, transparency and accountability.
We tried. There were a number of proposals. We tried to do it, but those were rejected. They will not be rejected that long because I think the time has come for different ways of making decisions, especially in the crucial area of Canadian foreign policy. The time is over when decisions like this one are to be made by those in the striped pants or the inside experts.
The reason is that if we expect Canadians to be engaged fully in the support of Canadian international actions-peace keeping, sanctions and sending troops abroad-then Canadians must be involved in making those decisions. The only way that we can build a consensus or an acceptance or legitimacy for such crucial decisions as these is to ensure that Canadians themselves are fully engaged and involved in the process; not after the fact, not at some time hence, not at some time when we get around to it, but when the decision is to be made.
The parliamentary secretary says: "Trust in us". As I said yesterday in the House, look what happened in the gulf war. It took six weeks for Parliament to be called back into session. If we ever wanted to see an example of why we should not trust a government, there it was right there. The ships were steaming to the Middle East. People were waving goodbye to their loved ones, and where were members of Parliament? There were back home tending their gardens, sitting in their constituency offices, and trying to answer questions of their constituents about why they were not in Ottawa having a debate about what Canada was doing over in the gulf.
To say that the standing orders account for it, the parliamentary secretary should know better. I expect he has read the standing orders. There is no standing order that allows Parliament to bring itself back. It is purely an executive decision, and this government has proven that executives make bad decisions; not just once, probably about 10 times a day. On this decision I do not think anybody can argue that it was a serious and fatal challenge to democratic accountability to keep Parliament in the dark for six weeks while we were engaged in one of the most serious initiatives taken since the Second World War. It was unacceptable to Canadians.
Maybe the parliamentary secretary is right. Maybe that is why they are paying an electoral price, because people
realize that there is an inherent disdain for parliamentary institutions and that there is an inherent arrogance: "Hey, we will look after it. Never mind asking questions or having debates in the House. We will make the best decision".
Unfortunately and tragically that same attitude was expressed even in the process by which this bill was made, the committee system itself. The parliamentary secretary was quite right. We had some valuable contributions: wheat pools, bankers, refugee organizations, humanitarian groups, Mennonite communities, all coming not in opposition to the bill but with constructive proposals.
They raised very serious questions. They said that the drafters of the bill were not omniscient, that they did not understand all the implications. They thought they could plug some of the loopholes and correct some of the problems. They thought that questions dealing with food and medicine should be given statutory exemption.
Is that a radical statement? If it is so radical, why is it included in the United Nations own rules dealing with it?
Would Canada be prepared to take such an extraordinary step even though the United Nations already does? Oh, no. The government's answer was: "Hey, we cannot trust these groups. Trust us. We will make that discretion". It did not listen to them. That is part of the regression of this legislation.
If we are legitimately to invite representation, not in a confrontational, partisan way, but in a legitimate way of people setting out their real concerns, and they get tossed out of hand as if they did not count for anything, how can we convince people out there that the system works? In fact it becomes a little bit of charade. It becomes a smoke screen: "Yes, we will have a committee. We will invite you to come. We will listen to you, but by goodness don't present anything that gets in the way of our game plan because we are going to roll right over you".
How are those people going to feel when they go back, that they were listened to, that they legitimately had a chance?
I cannot remember one representation from the committee that was antagonistic to the government. It was not a matter of politics being played. There is something inherently anachronistic, old boy school, fusty or maybe
May 6, 1992

it is just the control of power, that has the minister's officials, the departmental officials and MPs on the government side all getting together and saying: "Hey, we cannot accept this".
Why? Is it because they drafted it? Is it because it is good and every piece of legislation emerges out of the bowels of the government pristine perfect? Are they kidding me? Come on, we know better than that.
Here is a legitimate opportunity to show a give and take, a dynamic process of change and amendment, and what do we get? I think the government accepted maybe one or two amendments. It was something like that; it was nothing of consequence. It left out in the cold those groups who were saying: "During a sanctions program when we are deliberately trying to put pressure on the government of a target country, we have no business victimizing the people of that country. Therefore we want to ensure there is the right to deliver medicine, humanitarian goods, services and food".
Let me, if I might, quote for a minute Dr. Eric Hoskins, head of the Harvard study team on Iraq. It is dealing with the problems of Iraqi children and some of the problems that he and others have faced getting into this area. He says: "The procedure outlined in the bill is time consuming, ambiguous in deciding a permit for exemption, subject to bias, no longer accessible to many humanitarian workers, and completely impractical in acute emergency situations which by definition invariably require an immediate and urgent humanitarian response". That is from somebody who knows, who was there. However we did not listen to him, just as we did not listen to the banking association that said: "We have some problems here. Let us see if we can work something out". The pools, the same issue. The Canadian Mennonite community, the same problems. They were not being listened to. It shows the contrast.
If I can go back to the disturbing trend participating in this bill pointed out, it is the large gap between rhetoric and reality. The Prime Minister of this country loves to parade himself as the past co-chair of the children's summit, one of the great deliberations of our time. I applauded him at the time for the effort.
Let me read a key provision of the declaration which this government ratified at the convention on the rights
Government Orders
of the children: "In accordance with their obligation under international humanitarian law to protect the civilian population in armed conflicts, state parties shall take all feasible measures to ensure protection and care of children who are affected by an armed conflict".
I ask the Prime Minister where he was when his own government was turning down amendments and changes that would have provided the obligatory requirements to protect children in cases of conflict.
Where were you, Mr. Prime Minister? You were where you usually are. Once the photo opportunity is over, the reality sets in and you simply do not care any more.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext: There is a bit of misreading there.

I just heard the parliamentary secretary say there is a misreading. No, it is not a misreading. It is a mistake on the part of this government in failing to live up to the obligations it ratified last December.
Eventually that kind of decision-making will have to come to an end and will come to an end.
Finally I come back to one other point. I was amused by the summation of the parliamentary secretary when he said in so many words that this was a chance for Parliament to be involved. It struck me exceedingly strange, because that is the same gentleman who yesterday rejected amendments to ensure that when Parliament was not sitting there would be a requirement for the government to call it back into session to deal with these matters. He rejected an amendment which said that the minister responsible should be required to table reports outlining how sanctions are working so that Parliament and, through Parliament, Canadians can understand how children are being affected in Iraq, South Africa or wherever the sanctions may be. He is the same gentleman who rejected an amendment requiring that there not be such a large block of members for a debate to take place and that there be a certain amount of time.
The standing orders of the House do not provide the kinds of assurances and guarantees we need for parliamentary partnership in making these crucial decisions. Without those once again we are denying the very roots of our system unless we believe, as I suppose the parliamentary secretary seems to believe, that the Gov-

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
eminent of Canada is the executive of Canada, the cabinet of Canada, and said: "Oh, my goodness gracious, if we accept those amendments we will become like Americans".
I did not quite follow that large leap of logic because one of the geniuses of our parliamentary system is that when Parliament is in session it is able on a daily basis to question the executive and hopefully keep it honest as a result.
I will go back to my point. How can the opposition question the executive on a matter of imposing sanctions on a country if Parliament is not even being called back to discuss the matter?
I suppose the ministers, at least some of the ministers we have seen recently, prefer not to deal with committees or with Parliament. They avoid them. It is like pulling teeth to get them to come before committees. Do not tell me that they are eagerly awaiting the opportunity to make themselves heard or to defend their case. Hardly. I just wish the minister was here at third reading of this bill. Not that I have in any way underestimated the abilities of the parliamentary secretary, but this is the minister's bill and I have not seen the minister for months dealing with the bill in any way, shape or form. As the Secretary of State for External Affairs, this should be one of the most important initiatives taken and should have had the full guiding hand during that period.
The bill is here and third reading will take place. It will go on to our friends in the upper House who I hope and encourage will give it some careful scrutiny and make some suggestions for changes that we may want to consider and look at. I believe they were not given proper consideration here in the House of Commons, which is too often the case. However, that is for them to decide.
In the meantime I will conclude by lamenting a lost opportunity for this government and this Parliament to have taken a fairly bold and generous step forward as we work our way through a very turbulent and changing international environment, to provide some real leadership to other countries and to the international system on how to deal with this crucial issue. Unfortunately the bill takes a step back.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
The first two speakers under Standing Order 74 had 40 minutes if they
wanted to take it with no questions and comments. The next speaker will have 20 minutes plus questions and comments.

Mr. Speaker, it is an honour to rise to participate in the debate on this very important and historic legislation.
My colleagues in the New Democratic Party at second reading debate on the principle of this legislation strongly endorsed the principle of the bill. Indeed, it was my leader, the member for Yukon, and my colleagues in the New Democratic Party who at the critical time in January last year appealed to the community of nations, appealed to the United Nations not to proceed to the tragedy, the madness of war and instead ensure that tough, effective economic sanctions were given an opportunity to work in the context of the war in the gulf. We know that did not happen.
We know that the victims of that war continue to die today. Over 300 children a day are dying in Iraq, innocent victims of that war. Over 50,000 children have died so far.
Let me be very clear. We believe profoundly in the concept of common security. We believe strongly that the United Nations and other multilateral bodies must be strengthened, must be renewed to ensure that collective action can be taken in the case of significant breaches of international law and of grave threats to international peace and security.
Certainly there must be significant reform of those institutions, the United Nations and, indeed, of other multilateral institutions of which Canada is a member, including the OAS.
Many of us believe that the steps that were taken that ultimately led to the war in the gulf bypassed fundamentally not only the letter of the United Nations charter but the spirit and the intent of the United Nations charter. In effect, the United Nations was hijacked. The United States, in particular, was able to wrap itself in the flag of the UN and conduct a war that led to disastrous results, environmentally and in human terms.
We believe as well that sanctions must be consistent and that when, for example, the Secretary of State for External Affairs points out rightly that in the context of Haiti where a democratically elected president, President Aristide, was overthrown in a brutal military coup,

what better opportunity for collective action than that within the context of the OAS?
Yet, as the minister herself pointed out, some OAS members, including the United States, are abandoning their commitment to sanctions in the context of Haiti.
At the same time, the United States continues with its immoral stranglehold on the economy of Cuba, imposing an economic embargo which is cruel, unjust and unprecedented in its severity. There is no economic embargo on Indonesia with respect to its massive violations of human rights in East Timor, Guatemala or elsewhere. Yes, we believe fundamentally in sanctions, but surely we must also recognize that the community of nations must have common standards to ensure that the standards are not in fact riddled with hypocrisy.
In the context of this legislation, the bill which is before us, Bill C-53, we had an opportunity. As the member for Winnipeg South Centre stated, we had an opportunity to improve framework legislation, to ensure that we listened to the witnesses who appeared before the legislative committee. We had very compelling evidence from those witnesses. They were witnesses who themselves worked on the front lines in Cambodia, Iraq, Africa, Central America and elsewhere.
We heard evidence from the Canadian Friends Service Committee, the Canadian Arab Federation, the prairie pools, the bankers, the exporters, the Canadian Council on Refugees, the Mennonite Central Committee, the Ottawa Gulf Crisis Group, Dr. John Place, Professor Nakhjavani of McGill University and we heard from the national president of the United Nations Association of Canada, Geoffrey Grenville-Woods.
If there was one theme that was very clearly enunciated during the witnesses' appearances before the legislative committee, it was that this bill falls far short. Yes, we support the principles, and indeed I believe that all of the members and all of the witnesses who appeared before the committee supported the principles of the legislation, but they pointed out some very serious concerns, some very serious weaknesses in what the parliamentary secretary has referred to as framework legislation.
Government Orders
I want to just touch on some of these in this third reading debate. I hope that perhaps there might be some opportunity that the government might reconsider. Certainly the reality is that when this bill goes to the other place, it will correct a number of important weaknesses that remain in the legislation.
First of all, what is the threshold for the imposition of sanctions? It is at once too broad and too narrow. The legislation is very vague when it comes to who may actually make the decision, the fundamental decision which triggers some very, very significant economic sanctions.
On the other hand, it is too narrow in the sense that where there are grave violations of human rights which have occurred in a foreign state and which do not necessarily involve a threat to international peace and security or where the actions of foreign states or one foreign state pose a significant threat to the environment, either the global environment or the Canadian environment, there is no opportunity in those circumstances for Canada to take the kind of tough, effective action that we may very well want to be in a position to take under this legislation.
Second, in the provisions of the bill in clause 4, which deal with the seizure of assets, once again it is a very powerful remedy. It is one which in some circumstances is certainly appropriate and necessary.
The potential for abuse has been pointed out. It was pointed out by witnesses; abuse of innocent people, abuse of organizations which are doing important humanitarian work is very great.
The bill would allow the seizure of the assets in Canada of respected humanitarian organizations such as the Mennonite Central Committee, the Red Cross and other groups that are working in the humanitarian field in countries against which sanctions have been imposed. There is no assurance that the requirements with respect to a seizure might not allow the release of assets for solely humanitarian reasons. Yesterday I mentioned the proposal of Dr. Eric Hoskins and a number of very distinguished Canadians operating through Global Ed-Med Supplies whose chief patron is the Governor General and whose executive director is the Order of Canada winner, Doreen Wicks.

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
This group is seeking the release of assets to purchase infant formula and heart medicine for the Iraqi people who are dying. They have 856,000 tins of infant formula ready to go, 250,000 bottles of Isordel heart medicine, and still there is no action from the government.
The bill is not clear enough. In circumstances such as this, assets should be unfrozen to allow for the release of humanitarian goods.
As well, it is very important that we recognize that- [Translation]
The Canadian refugee council appeared before the committee and asked us to make sure the bill was amended to provide that refugees, persons claiming refugee status and claimants whose file is being processed for humanitarian reasons cannot have their property seized on the grounds that they are foreign nationals in Canada.
Mr. Speaker, we proposed amendments that would have made it clear that persons claiming refugee status who were not covered by international conventions would not be affected by our amendment. The Refugee Council explained that to meet our international obligations under the Geneva Convention on the Status of Refugees, which Canada signed in 1969, this bill must be amended to protect such refugees.

We have ignored the representations of the Canadian refugee council. We have ignored the representations of the humanitarian organizations, including Dr. Hoskins, with respect to the release of foods and medicines in times of war in which sanctions are being imposed.
This is despite the fact that the fourth international Geneva convention of 1949 explicitly prohibits any restrictions on the free passage of food and medicine, including during war time. We sought an amendment which I proposed on behalf of my New Democrat colleagues to build into the legislation those exemptions, exemptions in the key section of the bill with respect to sanctions against goods, sanctions against the transfer of technical data, sanctions against the transfer of services and services from Canada to another country.
The government systematically voted down each and every one of those amendments despite the eloquent representations that were made by witnesses before the committee and despite our obligations under international law.
The provisions of the bill with respect to compensation remain far too weak. Once again, we tried in committee to strengthen these. A number of witnesses made strong representations in this regard but to no avail. They fell on deaf ears on the government side. For example, we suggested that it should be mandatory that the government appoint a minister to consider claims for compensation. The government rejected that. It is particularly important that there be careful consideration given to claims for compensation in circumstances in which, for example, Parliament may reject the decision of the executive to impose sanctions.
The final area I would like to touch on in my remarks concerns the role of Parliament itself. The parliamentary secretary has said that this is framework legislation.
But, in fact, this legislation gives carte blanche to the executive, to the government of the day, to completely bypass Parliament in imposing sanctions. There is no requirement that Parliament be recalled if it is not sitting.
Many of us remember only too well the failure of the government of the day to recall Parliament in August of 1990 at a very critical time in the period leading up to the war in the gulf.
There is no requirement for full and comprehensive debate on the imposition of sanctions. The bill provides for a three-hour debate. Given the implications of this kind of legislation, surely that is not acceptable. Amendments were proposed and they, too, were rejected.
Finally, the bill makes no provision for ongoing review of the impact of sanctions. We tried in committee to persuade the government to accept an amendment which would ensure that there was a report every two or three months to the appropriate committee of Parliament, for example, the standing committee on external affairs, in order to enable us to review the impact of sanctions.
May 6, 1992

We know that certainly was not possible during the war in the gulf, one of the most heavily censored wars in global history. Presumably we should be learning the lessons of that war and of the tragic failure that that war engendered.
In conclusion, I want to once again express our support for the principle of this legislation, but also our tremendous sense of disappointment that the government has failed to respond to the witnesses who appeared before the committee.
Witnesses offered a number of important amendments to strengthen the legislation, to make clearer and more precise the circumstances in which sanctions might be imposed.
The amendments would have ensured that refugees and refugee claimants are not the victims of the seizure of their assets. In many cases those refugee claimants of course have fled the countries that have been targeted by sanctions.
The amendments would also have ensured that those who wish to provide desperately needed food, medicine and other humanitarian aid are able to do so without the kind of restrictions and impediments that are involved in the exemption and exclusion process, restrictions referred to by Dr. Hoskins in his evidence.
And finally, there were amendments which would have ensured a meaningful role for Parliament in this process, instead of simply rubber-stamping an executive decision.
As we heard from a number of witnesses, the fundamental concern in this legislation which is not addressed is that if nations and their leaders are subject to sanctions, we do not intend to make war on civilians or the environment.
Under the terms of this legislation there remains a risk that innocent people will continue to die, that innocent people will continue to be victims of economic sanctions. We very much regret that. We made an attempt in committee to strengthen the legislation.
Certainly I would hope that in the very near future in this country there will be an opportunity for us as a government to ensure that the principles of equity, of fairness, of justice prevail in this legislation as in other legislation in this country.
