speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (for the Minister of National Defence) moved
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
that Bill C-77, an act to amend the National Defence Act be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.
She said: Mr. Speaker, it is my pleasure today to speak in support of this bill, given first reading in this House on Monday, which proposes amendments to the National Defence Act.
Having had discussions with colleagues on both sides of the House, I understand that there maybe a predisposition to move this bill forward to committee of the whole and third reading following second reading debate if time allows today.
I also hope that members who have had the chance to examine this very short bill will agree with me that its provisions are well justified and deserve to be passed quickly by the House.
I would like to spend a bit of time giving the background to this bill and the military justice system. I know many people are not that familiar with it.
We live in very dynamic legal times. This has been so for the past 10 years since the coming into effect of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. In that time, the government has spent a great deal of effort on legislative amendments designed to bring our existing legal structures into conformity with the charter.
In some cases, however, we have had to wait for the interpretation of the Supreme Court of Canada on various charter provisions. Once we have received those court decisions we have reacted, sometimes on very short notice, by amending the affected legislation.

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
As an example, hon. members will recall that the government passed amendments to the Criminal Code and various other statutes just last year. These amendments were required because of a Supreme Court of Canada decision regarding the disposition of persons who were found at trial to be mentally incompetent.

Mr. Speaker, the bill tabled today also arises from an interpretation that the Supreme Court gave us on a specific point of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. As a result of a ruling that the Supreme Court rendered in February 1992, the National Defence Act must be slightly amended to comply with the requirements of the charter.

In a few minutes I will discuss the nature of the specific amendments we are proposing. First, I would like to indicate the general subject area of these amendments and that is the code of service discipline. I know my colleague from Bonavista-Trinity-Conception is, perhaps, more familiar than even I am with this code having lived with it during his time in the Canadian Armed Forces.
I would like to take a few minutes just to put this subject into context. To understand the military justice system in Canada, one must first understand that it is part of an over-all program for the enforcement of discipline in the Canadian forces.
It is no exaggeration to say that the essential element in military success is always discipline. In war and in particular, modern war, the successful force will be the disciplined force. This is especially true for countries with modest-sized forces, such as Canada.
The reputation of our forces for effectiveness and efficiency, a reputation for which Canadians have good reason to be proud, is built in significant measure on the internal discipline which is a feature of the life of the forces.
Of course, the strongest discipline in a soldier is self-discipline. From the moment that a recruit is enrolled, the Canadian forces concentrate on instilling self-discipline. This is done in both group and individual
training, relying primarily on positive motivation and feedback.
Disciplined behaviour is strongly encouraged and rewarded. Soldiers learn quickly that the undisciplined simply cannot get the military job done. For the great majority of young Canadians who enter military service, this positive training is enough to instil the self-discipline that in turn leads to unit pride and accomplishment.
For a small number of soldiers however, positive reinforcement is not enough to maintain discipline. The Canadian forces therefore needs a mechanism to impose punishment in cases of undisciplined behaviour.
This mechanism must be constantly visible, visible to the soldier and credible in his or her eyes, whether in peacetime or in war. To be credible it needs to be designed and operated in keeping with the realities of military service. It has to operate quickly. It has to be available wherever our troops are deployed. It has to be consistent and it has to be fair.
Most important, the soldier has to believe that it is consistent and fair. A system that does not recognize basic human values simply will not be effective with our professional all-volunteer force.
This point cannot be over-emphasized. It is not in the interest of the Canadian forces or the Canadian people to try to impose a disciplinary system in the military which is not in accord with fundamental Canadian values.
The foundation of the disciplinary system of the Canadian forces is the code of service discipline which constitutes the largest single part of the National Defence Act.
The code has two essential elements, first a description of the various offences that military personnel may commit. These include such purely military matters as disobedience of a lawful command, desertion, mutiny, and so on. Also included are criminal offences from civilian life, such as theft or assault.
The second element of the code is a system for the trial of charges which are laid against soldiers. The code of service discipline provides for a completely separate
May 6, 1992

system from that which Canadians are used to for the administration of penal justice.
This system includes a hierarchy of tribunals by which members of the Canadian forces can be tried if they are charged with service offences.
The lowest level of tribunal is the summary trial. The great majority of military trials are of this type. Summary trials are held before a commanding officer who has limited powers of punishment. These trials are normally used to deal with minor disciplinary offences, particularly those which arise in a training context.
Summary trials, as their name implies, can be held quickly within the unit. The results are highly visible to other members of the unit thereby enhancing discipline.
Substantial safeguards are in place to ensure that these summary trials are fair. In particular, these safeguards include the right of the accused to elect to be tried by a higher tribunal if any significant punishment is proposed.
In the military justice system the higher tribunals are called courts martial. As with much of Canadian criminal law our military justice system has its origins in British law. The court martial has been a feature of the British military system for several hundred years. In fact, it is also passed down to our various allies who share our heritage of common law.
While there are minor differences between the court martial systems in, for example, Canada, Australia, the United States and of course, Great Britain, all of these systems provide for the trial of military members by other military persons.
In particular, all systems have types of court martial which involve a military judge sitting with a panel of officers. The function of the panel is analogous to that of a jury at a civilian trial.
One might ask whether it is necessary to have this separate system of justice in which military members sit in judgment over their own. The short answer to this question is yes.
Let me quote in fact to the House from the recent judgment of the Supreme Court of Canada which has given rise in fact to the bill now before us. In discussing
Government Orders
the purpose of a system of military tribunals Chief Justice Lamer spoke as follows:
The purpose of a separate system of military tribunals is to allow the Armed Forces to deal with matters that pertain directly to the discipline, efficiency, and morale of the military. The safety and wellbeing of Canadians depends considerably on the willingness and readiness of a force of men and women to defend against threats to the nation's security. To maintain the Armed Forces in a state of readiness, the military must be in a position to enforce internal discipline effectively and efficiently. Breaches of military discipline must be dealt with speedily and, frequently, punished more severely than would be the case if a civilian engaged in such conduct. As a result, the military has its own Code of Service Discipline to allow it to meet its particular disciplinary needs. In addition, special service tribunals, rather than the ordinary courts, have been given jurisdiction to punish breaches of the Code of Service Discipline. Recourse to the ordinary criminal courts would, as a general rule, be inadequate to serve the particular disciplinary needs of the military.
Further on in the judgment Chief Justice Lamer states again:
The existence of a parallel system of military law and tribunals, for the purpose of enforcing discipline in the military, is deeply entrenched in our history and is supported by the compelling principles discussed above.
Hon. members may be interested in knowing a little more about the Canadian system of courts martial, which in an indirect way is the subject of the legislation before the House. There are four kinds of courts martial in the Canadian system. Two involve a military legal officer, trained as a judge, sitting alone. The other two, called general and disciplinary courts martial, involve the military judge sitting with a panel of officers called the president and members of the court.
Courts martial have varying jurisdictions and powers of punishment. The purely military offences I mentioned a few minutes ago can only be tried by general or disciplinary courts martial, the two categories in which there is a military jury. The amendments now before the House are concerned only with these two categories.
With respect to territorial jurisdiction, Canadian forces courts martial may sit anywhere in the world. They are however prohibited from trying offences involving homicide and sexual assault when these offences are committed in Canada.
I want to emphasize that trials by court martial in the Canadian forces are relatively rare, reflecting the high standard of discipline in the forces. There are usually fewer than 100 trials by court martial each year, and

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
incarceration of any kind is awarded in less than half of those cases.
Nevertheless, the court martial system is important. It must continue to have the flexibility to provide speedy trials at remote locations. To ensure the prompt enforcement of a fair and visible system of military justice Canadian forces courts martial have been held in recent years in places where our troops have been deployed, for example, the United Kingdom, Jamaica, Puerto Rico, the Golan Heights and Cyprus.
Members should also have a clear understanding of the relationship between the Charter of Rights and Freedoms and the Canadian Armed Forces. Some Canadians might be under the impression that the Canadian forces are in some way exempt from the essential elements of Canadian law which protect the rights of all Canadians. Nothing could be further from the truth.
The charter is the supreme law of the land. This means that every member of the Canadian forces enjoys exactly the same protection before the law, including military law, as any other Canadian citizen. For example, Canadian soldiers enjoy the same protection against unreasonable search and seizure, against arbitrary detention and against the unequal application of the law as other citizens do.
When a Canadian soldier runs afoul of criminal law he or she has the same right as any other Canadian to counsel, the same right to remain silent, the same right to know why he or she has been arrested or detained, and all the same rights of trial, including a court martial.
In short, the Canadian Armed Forces do not operate in a vacuum. Canadian domestic law, particularly law designed for the protection of individual rights, applies fully to the Canadian forces. This has been recognized all along by the forces. The fundamental mission of the Canadian forces is to uphold Canadian society and its values and not to try to live outside the law.
In summary, we are addressing the coming together of two essential elements in Canadian society. The first is the proud Canadian tradition of an effective and dedicated military force founded on the essential quality of discipline. The second is that fundamental respect for
individual rights that forms the very basis of our society. These two elements have historically stood together in Canada and will continue to do so.
Let me turn now to a more specific consideration of the amendments put forward in the bill before the House. The purpose of these amendments is to fine tune the Code of Service Discipline to ensure full compliance with the charter as recently interpreted by the Supreme Court of Canada.
A few moments ago I spoke about the general and disciplinary courts martial, the two types of courts in which military members sit as a kind of jury. In its recent judgment the Supreme Court of Canada considered whether such courts could be truly independent and impartial as is required by the charter. The Supreme Court stated clearly that our parallel system of military tribunals, staffed by members of the military who are aware of and sensitive to military concerns, is not by its nature inconsistent with the requirement of the charter.
However, the Supreme Court did express its disapproval of some of the means by which these military juries-if I may call them that-are selected and appointed. In particular the court noted that under the current system the selection and appointment of members of a court martial is carried out by the same senior military authority, called the convening authority, who has made the decision to put a certain member on trial.
The Supreme Court noted as well that it is the same military authority who also selects the prosecutor. In considering whether a court appointed in this way could truly appear to be independent the Supreme Court expressed concerns over the fact that all of these roles are in one set of hands, that of the convening authority.
To repeat, these roles involve the decisions to put the accused on trial, appoint the prosecutor, and select and appoint the members of the court.
The Supreme Court held that the principle of institutional independence requires that a court martial be free from external interference in matters relating to its judicial function. The court considered that this freedom is not apparent when a member of the military executive responsible for appointing the prosecutor also has the authority to select and appoint members of the court martial.
May 6, 1992

Thus to comply with the charter the appointment of members should be in the hands of a military authority other than the one who appoints the prosecutor.

Mr. Speaker, the main purpose of the amendments contained in the bill is to ensure the separation of these powers. The bill provides that the task of choosing and appointing the members of a court martial will be given to a senior military officer who is not involved in the disciplinary process and is totally independent of both the prosection and the defence.

In other minor ways the proposed amendments reduced the links between the military executive and the members of the court who are appointed to try a given individual. For example, the authority convening a court martial could formerly decide within a prescribed range how many members could sit on the particular court. That number will now be fixed by statute.
Similarly, in the past the military executive could pass regulations limiting the role of the military judge in deciding questions of law at courts martial, that power of limitation is now being removed.
Also, along the same lines, the convening authority has previously been empowered to exclude the public in certain limited circumstances from a trial by court martial. The bill would remove that power from the convening authority, however the court itself would retain it just as a civilian court does in an ordinary trial.
I think there is one more proposed change worthy of mention. As a result of the fact that the members of a court martial will be appointed by an authority at arm's length from both the accused and the prosecution we have considered it advisable to allow the prosecution for the first time to object to individual members appointed to the court.
Formerly, only the accused could object. Thus, under the proposed new regime the system will again be similar to that of civilian criminal courts in which both sides can object to specific members of a proposed jury.
I have touched on all but one or two very small changes contained in this bill. The minor changes that I have not mentioned are also directly related to the aim
Government Orders
of reducing any possible perception that the military executive could interfere with the proper judicial functioning of a court martial.
I would like to add a word or two about the urgency of these amendments. Since the decision of the Supreme Court in mid-February it has been impossible to hold trials either by general or disciplinary court martial. The Canadian forces have therefore been deprived of the use of these essential tools in our disciplinary system, and not surprisingly a backlog of cases has built up and continues to build.
I hope that all hon. members will recognize that although the amendments contained in this bill are somewhat technical they are nonetheless essential. They will not in any way harm the operational effectiveness of the forces. In fact, they are vital to that operational effectiveness.
Finally, these amendments raise no policy issues except for the continuing policy, which I know that all hon. members will support, of ensuring that this important aspect of Canadian law complies fully with the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
In moving that this bill now be read a second time I ask all members to support its speedy passage.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to compliment my hon. colleague, the hon. Associate Minister of National Defence, on her discussion of the purpose of the amendment to the National Defence Act, the derivation of its need and the necessity of this amendment.
The minister made a first class presentation of the continuing need for a military justice system and Code of Service Discipline. She said that this amendment guarantees that the military Code of Service Discipline and the military justice system will be consistent with our other code of discipline and the ultimate test, which is the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
I want to speak on the bill as well, perhaps in the same kind of tone as the minister. As she suggested at the outset, I will be speaking from a slightly different perspective, having been required over a few years to see the system in operation and to be allowed to make an independent judgment, sometimes stated and sometimes not, on the efficacy and justness of that system.

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
Suffice it to say, members could probably prejudge what my conclusion would be. I was very pleased to see this amendment because I had anticipated it for some time. As I discussed this informally with the minister before we made these presentations I could tell that we were both glad. I am sure that other colleagues in the House familiar with this system are equally pleased.
The bill essentially, as the minister pointed out, provides some technical amendments. They are technical in a sense, but in some ways they are involved with principle. The principle is that it allows the military justice system to continue by bringing it in line with the charter.
quires punishment more severe, not less severe as some people would suggest, than would be the case if a civilian engaged in such conduct.
As a result, the military has its own Code of Service Discipline to allow it to meet its own particular disciplinary military needs. It falls from that that special service tribunals like a disciplinary court martial, a general court martial or a summary trial, as was again described by the minister, has to exist to allow breaches in the Code of Service Discipline to be effectively dealt with. The corollary of that of course is that recourse to the ordinary criminal courts would be inappropriate, inadequate and perhaps untimely to serve this particular disciplinary need.
If somebody were to hear me say this and take it out of context, they could perhaps ask: "Are you saying then that the military system has not been in line with the charter since it was brought into existence?" Some may answer yes, and some may answer no. The fact that it has taken many years to bring this amendment along, and the weight of the Supreme Court having to be brought to make the decision that ends up in these amendments, is an indication that the very amendments that we are talking about here today were at least judgmental and did take some time to develop. Perhaps I would be allowed to touch on those aspects as well.
We do have a separate system of military justice. The purpose of that is to allow the Canadian Armed Forces to deal with matters that relate directly to discipline, efficiency and the morale of the military, which is essential.
The defence of our country, as was pointed out by the minister and reports on this subject, depends very much on the motivation and the readiness of those men and women who serve in the Canadian Armed Forces to be prepared to protect against any threat to our national security. That requires them to be mobile, to be in the field and to be away from the normal system of doing things in our country.
For the armed forces to remain in a state of readiness, the military must be capable of enforcing internal discipline quickly, effectively and efficiently. If there is a breach of military discipline, it has to be dealt with quickly and sometimes, depending on the situation and where the unit is, regrettably frequently. It often re-
I think that is an indication of why we do need and will continue to need for as long as we can see a separate system of military justice. I think those involved in the business can defend it with little difficulty.
I would now like to bring into my presentation three aspects of the charter because I am going to refer to them later on. Article 1 of the charter, which is very general, sets out that:
The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms guarantees the rights and freedoms set out in it subject only to such reasonable limits prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society.
That is a general statement that basically confers legality on the whole discussion here today.
Article 11(f) I think is important because of the nature of what we are discussing here today. It says:
Any person charged with an offence has the right
(f) except in the case of an offence under military law tried before a military tribunal, to the benefit of a trial by jury where the maximum punishment for the offence is imprisonment for five years or a more severe punishment;
This article recognizes the existence of a military tribunal.
The item that is very pertinent to our discussion today is article 11(d) which says that:
Any person charged with an offence has the right
(d) to be presumed innocent until proven guilty according to law in a fair and public hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal;
The crux of the discussion today is has the system of military justice been fair, has it been independent and has it been impartial?

May 6, 1992

A court martial is a very serious business. It has a structure, a fairly simple structure, in which you have the members of the court martial. They are the tryers of fact. You have a representative of the Judge Advocate General, generally called the Judge Advocate. His job is to preside over the proceedings very much like a judge. He is chosen from the ranks of the militaiy. The members of the court martial, or courts martial in the plural sense, must be of the rank of captain or higher. They are trained in this business. Their training is designed to ensure that they are sensitive to the needs of discipline, obedience and duty on the part of the members of the military, and also to the requirement of military efficiency.
In that sense, the court martial represents to an extent the concerns of those persons who are responsible for the discipline and morale of the military.
A reasonable person might well consider that the military status of a court martial's members would affect its approach to the matters that come before it for decision.
The whole question, as I understand it, being determined by the Supreme Court of Canada, and what really resulted in this change being made here today, was the perception in the case of a reasonable person who had knowledge, both of the law and of the military justice system, whether he would be perceived to be independent and impartial.
Before I go on I want to quote, if I may, an opinion which indicates to me, and I hope to you and the House, that this was not an easy decision to make. I am going to quote a good friend of mine, who served with great distinction and was awarded the Order of Military Merit in the Canadian Forces, Colonel Jim Fay, who is an acknowledged authority in the business. He prepared a study of Canadian military law entitled Canadian Military Criminal Law: An Examination of Military Justice. Colonel Fay and I had many a discussion on the fairness of military trials, the very subject that we are discussing here today.
I am going to quote what Colonel Fay had to say because it gives, if not the other side of the coin, some indication of the difficulties one encounters in deciding what is fair and what is impartial and what is independent in the military system of justice. He says and I quote: "In a military organization such as the Canadian
Government Orders
forces there cannot ever be a truly independent military judiciary. The reason is that the military officer must be involved in the administration of discipline at all levels. A major strength of the present military judicial system rests in the use of trained military officers who are also legal officers to sit on courts martial in judicial roles. If this connection were to be severed, and true independence could only be achieved by such severance, the advantage of independence of the judge that might thereby be achieved would be more than offset by the disadvantage of the eventual loss by the judge of the military knowledge and experience which today helps him to meet his responsibilities effectively. Neither the forces nor the accused would benefit from such a separation."
Clearly, when this was written there was some belief from a lifetime of military judgment and military discipline in the experience of a judge that it would be very difficult to achieve fairness, independence and impartiality in the total military sense if military judges were to be totally removed from the system.
The definition of independence, as seen by the Supreme Court of Canada, really hinged on three things: The security of tenure; financial security; and institutional independence. It was believed that the Judge Advocate at general courts martials did not enjoy sufficient security of tenure. The Judge Advocate General is one of the three people in national defence appointed by the Governor in Council; the deputy minister and the Chief of Defence Staff being the other two. He is not independent but is really part of the executive. He serves as an agent of the executive in supervising prosecutions. That is his job.
Furthermore, the regulations in force, and I am talking about the National Defence Act, at the time of the trial that led to this decision, the Judge Advocate was appointed on a case by case basis. As a result it was believed that there was no effective guarantee that his career as a military judge would not be affected by the decisions tending to favour the accused rather than the prosecution.
Here again, a reasonable person might well have entertained a fear or an apprehension that a person chosen as a Judge Advocate had been selected because he had satisfied the interests of the executive, or at least

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
he had not disappointed executive expectations in his appointment. Therefore, the conclusion was that it was questionable. It was decided eventually that the military judge in this particular case, under the particular system where the judge was appointed by the executive, did not qualify.
The second question was one of financial security. Here the argument was that a military legal officer's salary is determined, in part, because of his performance evaluation and his performance evaluation is determined by his immediate superior. In the case of maritime command, his immediate superior was the deputy commander. Consultation was always held with the Judge Advocate with respect to the performance of that particular officer. I think the point was that his future was very much affected by the executive.
There were no formal prohibitions at the time these decisions were made against evaluating an officer on the basis of his performance at a general court martial. The belief was that his performance at a court martial was part of his general performance and, perhaps, it would be difficult to separate the two. The point was that the executive had the ability by virtue of his preparation of the performance evaluation to interfere with the salaries and promotional opportunities of officers serving as Judge Advocates and members at a court martial.
Although the practice of the executive may very well have been to respect the independence of the participants at the court martial in this respect, it was not sufficient to correct the weakness in the tribunal status. Once again, a reasonable person would perceive that financial security was not present in this case.
If I could be permitted a parenthetical comment, it would be very difficult to cite a case where it could be shown directly where a performance evaluation was decided on a performance, either as a member of a court martial or as a judge at a court martial. As you know, Mr. Speaker, when people judge other people, what is objective and what is not objective? The point here is that on the toss of the judicial coin, if I could use that expression, the benefit was given to the accused and the benefit given to the person on trial on the basis that he is innocent until proven guilty. Certainly, from my discussions with my colleagues they believed that seemed to be a very reasonable approach to life.
The third thing was the institutional independence of the tribunal, once again in the minds of a reasonable and informed person. I just talked about and quoted Colonel Jim Fay on using other than military judges and military officers to perform as judge and jury in the case of an accused. Notwithstanding that, the Supreme Court, in looking at legislation governing the general court martial, revealed to them that military officers who were responsible to their superiors in the Department of National Defence were intimately involved in the proceedings of the tribunal.
In particular, it was unacceptable that the authority that convened the court martial, that is the executive who is responsible for also appointing the prosecutor, should have the authority to appoint members of the court martial to serve as tryers of fact. The appointment of the Judge Advocate by the Judge Advocate General also undermined the institutional independence of the general court martial, the point being that the close tie between the Judge Advocate General who was appointed by the Governor in Council and the executive was obvious.
The belief and the judgment was to comply with section 11(d) of the charter, which I read a few moments ago, which talked about an independent and impartial tribunal. The appointment of a military judge to sit as a Judge Advocate at a particular court martial should be in the hands of an independent and impartial judicial officer. That was the basis of the judgments that were made.
As the minister pointed out, what essentially has happened is that amendments have been made to the National Defence Act which cover those areas that cause concern essentially with the executive or the officer who convenes the court martial also appointing the judge and also having certain discretionary powers, that are now with this amendment, taken away from him.
I suppose the other aspect of this is that now a convening authority has less total authority in the conduct of both a general court martial and a disciplinary court martial and less discretion with respect to removing the convening authorities power to exclude the public from a trial. That does not exist anymore. Mem-
May 6, 1992

bers of a court martial are appointed as a statutory number as opposed to giving the convening authority an option.
I am delighted to say that we discussed this among our colleagues and we are quite prepared to give the bill our seal of approval. We are delighted to do so because of the background that I put forward.
Before closing, I want to reaffirm to the Canadian public that the military Code of Service Discipline is necessary. It is fair. It is perhaps as fair as any system can be. I am convinced this amendment makes the system of military justice totally consistent with the charter and with the Canadian system of justice.
Before I sit down I would, having been so kind to my colleague, the Associate Minister of National Defence, remind her that there are some other areas of legislation. The National Defence Act has not been overhauled in some time. I remember working on it back in 1978. It was some years before it came for discussion in this House. I see the minister smiling. She is aware that there are certain aspects of the National Defence Act that need in a positive sense streamlining, that need overhauling and that need to be discussed here on the floor of the House of Commons.
First, we need legislation that tidies up the business of what parliamentarians have to do before our country considers itself at war. We went through a great period of confusion during the Persian Gulf discussions. Essentially the government of the day committed the country without recalling Parliament. That was a very serious error in judgment.
I would like to see and I believe I am speaking for my colleagues and other members of the House-this is not meant as a political ploy, it is an impartial statement-we really do have to tidy up that business about the requirement to recall Parliament before you send your country to war. The definition of what is meant by active service is pretty messy right now and it needs to be tidied up.
The second point I would like to raise is really for the minister's benefit. I know that one of the principles of national defence today, as it has been for a few years now, is the total force concept in which the use of
Government Orders
reserves, both supplementary ready reserves and primary reserves, are essential.
In order to make that policy effective, which I support and my party supports, we really need legislation to tidy away the legal niceties of this aspect. I know it is going to be very difficult but until this happens I think we are going to have to start that long road uphill to get that legislation under way.
The only way we are going to do it is to introduce legislation, go public, get public reaction, and hone it. It will take years but I really do believe in my heart of hearts that we need to get on with it.
I have been speaking a little longer than normal but I felt it was necessary to go through it in that detail. I thank the members of the House for their indulgence.

Mr. Speaker, I rise on behalf of the New Democratic Party to speak at second reading of the bill. We too will support the bill and will accommodate the usual procedures by agreeing that we should consider the matter in committee of the whole, if we can proceed that way. We appreciate that the bill is urgent and needs to be dealt with promptly.
The bill, as set out by the minister, is an amendment to the National Defence Act in a very narrow and specific area. The Supreme Court of Canada in February of this year found that in certain respects the court martial procedures under the National Defence Act are counter to the charter.
Some of the areas were cleared up by regulation but one remained. Essentially it was the broad issue of the selection of the judge and jury which the court found procedurally lacked independence. In order to assure the independence required by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms this bill is before the House.
I appreciate what the bill does to take away from the prosecutor, the convening officer, the right to appoint- in effect the judge and jury to deal with the court-and has set up a far more independent system so that the accused will be entitled to be tried by an independent tribunal.
We support the bill. Specifically the way in which this is achieved is to remove the convening authority's power to appoint the president and members of the court. The bill also provides that an officer other than the convening authority designated by the regulations made by the Governor in Council will do the appointing of the

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
president and the members. We have had it explained to us that the proposed system will be a random selection from among those serving in the forces.
The conveying authority's power also will be removed. The power to prevent a court martial from making a finding of guilty or not guilty on a charge where the charge alleges an attempt to commit an offence that power will be removed and it will turn on the evidence before the court.
The bill will remove the convening authority's power to exclude the public from a trial. The bill will remove the statutory authority available to the military hierarchy to limit the role of the Judge Advocate in deciding questions of law and mixed law in fact. It will remove the convening authority's discretion to vary the number the officers constituting a general court martial and a disciplinary court martial and to establish that the required number of officers will always be five in the case of general court martial and three in the case of disciplinary court martial, the current minimum numbers prescribed for these courts.
The bill will also provide that both the prosecution and the accused may object for cause to the members and the Judge Advocate appointed for the court. Finally it will allow consequential amendments to the act consistent with the above points.
On the understanding that that is what the bill in fact does, then we support it. It has been clearly undertaken to us that the bill now is in full compliance with the Canadian charter and that the court martial proceedings now comply with the charter.
We agree that it is urgent because we understand there are at least 20 or 30 cases now that are awaiting the improvement in the procedures. Until the procedures are brought into line with the charter, these cases cannot proceed. Justice requires that Parliament deal with this very quickly. As long as we can be assured that the bill does what we are told it does, then we can proceed with it.
I have had an opportunity to talk with an official with the Canadian Bar Association. She made it clear to me that she was not going to be able to reflect the official position of the Canadian Bar Association on this. As a result of those discussions I believe that the assurances we received are correct. My own review of the bill also
leads me to that conclusion. I suppose if we are all H incorrect some court some day will tell us.	H
However, on the understanding that the bill brings the H procedures into conformity with the Canadian Charter H of Rights and Freedoms, then of course it has our	H
support. In view of the requirements for urgency we are	H
prepared to accommodate that.	H
However, before I sit down, I want to deal with a H couple of other related issues. First of all, while this H aspect of the military court martial proceedings would H now appear to be fixed, there may be other areas in the H administration of justice within the military that need H| some examination.
It has been brought to my attention, for example, that the prison in Edmonton is a particularly backward and regressive institution; that it is run in what was described a Victorian manner and that a strong case could be made for taking a look at what is going on within that prison. Perhaps in the larger context we should look at the way in which those who are charged with offences or convicted of offences that require incarceration are kept and maintained and whether that is consistent with the norms that the government and the Parliament of Canada is seeking to impose in the correction system in general.
I will undertake to draw to the minister's attention any specifics in this that have been brought to my attention and would look forward to her undertaking to look into that.
There is another area that has also been brought to my attention and that is the issue of legal aid for those who are charged with offences. My understanding of the procedure is that legal assistance is provided. It seems to me that it is an important element in our system of justice in this country that an individual has the right to have counsel of his or her own choosing.
There are obvious limits on that and the limits apply within the legal aid system. Still our legal aid system as it applies in most provinces, and is supported by the financial assistance of the government, attempts to provide a degree of accessibility to that right of choice for counsel, and as well as the opportunity to seek experienced counsel in difficult and important cases. As I say, it has been brought to my attention that these

May 6, 1992

principles need some application in the case of the Canadian military.
I would hope that as we are now talking about the administration of justice, or at least one aspect of it, we can use this occasion to bring that concern to the floor of the House of Commons and to the minister.
This amendment offers me another opening. My friend from the Liberal Party has done that in part. What we have in front of us is an amendment to the National Defence Act. It is in front of the House because of the Supreme Court decision which struck down the court martial procedures and forced the Department of National Defence to respond to that decision. The only way it could do so was to bring an amendment before the House.
However, as my friend said earlier, this House has heard other requests for amendments to the National Defence Act. The time has surely come to begin to take a very serious look at all aspects of the National Defence Act and not wait until the Supreme Court of Canada has forced the situation.
Yesterday before the defence committee the minister gave some useful assurances in response to a question of mine on that issue. I would hope that she would take this opportunity to reaffirm the commitment that she has made on behalf of the government to launch a review of the National Defence Act.
As my friend said earlier, this will take some time. Though I must say that it always puzzles me why it has to take as long as these things do, when there is urgency the system can apparently respond. However, there are a number of issues that need a careful look, and I would like to list them and put them on the record of this Parliament.
There were at least two issues that came up in the Oka crisis, in which the Canadian forces were involved, that require a review of the provisions of the National Defence Act. The first is the issue of cost. The forces in Oka were called out under the provisions of part 11 of the National Defence Act, with which the provincial governments can call to their assistance the Canadian forces. The Canadian forces are obliged to respond to that call under the terms of the National Defence Act in aid of the civil power.
The constitutional responsibility for law and order at that level is with the provincial governments. The
Government Orders
Canadian military, which is a federal responsibility, is being called to aid the provinces in narrow limited circumstances.
However, the bill is charged to the federal government and the federal taxpayer. There ought to be a review of those provisions. In my view it will necessitate amendments to the National Defence Act to clear that up. That is something which I would hope the government will look at.
There is a second and perhaps even more serious matter. That concerns the constraints that may be properly applied to the Canadian forces when they are called up to serve under that provision of the act in aid of the civil power. A few years ago this Parliament undertook a very comprehensive review of the War Measures Act and came up with the necessary balance between the needs of the state for order and the use of the military to maintain order, and on the other hand the rights of Canadians, as described in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, in emergency circumstances.
A very elaborate and intricate system exists in the Emergencies Act to ensure that when the Canadian forces are called up under that act certain reports are made to Parliament and certain other constraints written in which would not constrain the forces from doing the duty that they have to do but would ensure within reasonable limits that Canadian rights and freedoms are protected.
None of those provisions apply when the Canadian forces are called up under part 11 in aid of the civil power. There need to be amendments to the National Defence Act to ensure that either the provisions of the Emergencies Act apply or some other reasonable provisions would apply in those cases so that the rights of Canadians are properly governed.
As well, we obviously need to tighten up the reporting provisions of that part of the act because we have never had a satisfactory report from the Government of Quebec on the use of the forces in that situation. That is clearly necessary and should be included.
Second, during the gulf war we saw another weakness in the provisions of the act that need review. When the government puts Canadian forces in a combat situation there should be clear provisions for the approval of Parliament of that action, as had been the tradition in this country prior to the gulf war. Furthermore, there should be clear provisions for consultation with the leadership in Parliament when the government is obliged

May 6, 1992
Government Orders
to act quickly in an emergency and when Parliament is not in session.
I believe that all Canadians and all parties in this House would want those provisions in the National Defence Act. The time has come for them to be considered.
There are a number of other provisions I would just like to refer to. One is the issue of freedom of conscience. Our charter now provides freedom of conscience to Canadians, but that right is not given those serving in the Canadian forces. It is possible for this Parliament to design an opportunity for those serving in the forces to exercise their real freedom of conscience in appropriate circumstances consistent with their obligations as members of the forces.
Another is the use of the death penalty. Throughout the penalty provisions in the National Defence Act the death penalty is given as a possible penalty for an offence under the National Defence Act. It is crucial that fact be reviewed in view of the continued expression of this Parliament that the death penalty is not an appropriate penalty.
I do not want to prejudge the case as to whether there may conceivably be a case in a military situation in which the death penalty should be retained, although at this stage I will be very hard to persuade on that case.
I am sure that almost all members of this House are at the other end of the spectrum and the fact that there are provisions in the National Defence Act for the application of the death penalty is horrifying and could completely offend every member of this House.
The military may say: "Oh, well, we would not use it in that circumstance". Well, that is not good enough and it should be reviewed in light of the expressions of views of this House.
There is a need to examine a peace tax fund. It has been proposed across this country. There are many people in this country who, as a matter of conscience, do not wish to contribute to the military. Other countries have looked at this proposal. We can look at ways of providing an opportunity for those who, as a matter of conscience, want to have their tax dollars go to a peace tax fund for non-military purposes.
Yesterday I raised with the minister the question of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which provides that children 15 years or younger should not be recruited into the forces. We need to ensure that the provisions of the National Defence Act are consistent with that convention.
There are three other quick issues that I would like to raise under this heading. The next is the issue of nuclear weapons. Canada does not itself directly use military weapons in its defence. We have been part of collective security arrangements in which nuclear weapons are held in threat to be used, but we have not directly used them ourselves. Canadians across this country have raised very serious objections to the storage of nuclear weapons on Canadian soil and on our reliance on nuclear weapons, albeit indirectly.
It is very clear to many Canadians that even the threat of nuclear weapons is contrary to international law and the norms of international justice. Any country that purported to use nuclear weapons would be offending the fundamental values we hold as Canadians, and which are set out in the United Nations Charter. However the Department of National Defence continues to approve visits to this country of vessels which may well contain nuclear weapons. The day in which we do that is over. The act should provide for restraints on the circumstances under which nuclear weapons are allowed to be brought into Canada and/or stored in this country.
My friend has raised the issue of reserves. It is very clear that needs to be dealt with under the amendments to the National Defence Act.
Finally there is the issue of the rights of gays and lesbians, which the minister has already addressed in committee and on the floor of this House. We are expecting an announcement, we hope shortly, that gays and lesbians within the forces will have their rights protected and there will no longer be discrimination against them.
In light of history it seems to me that it would be helpful if there was an amendment to the National Defence Act to cover that as well.
With those comments I would say that we will support this bill on second reading and we hope that we can proceed quickly this afternoon to examine it in commit-

tee of the whole so that it could possibly be adopted by this House today.
