That, in the opinion of this House, the government should consider the advisability of upgrading the rail link to Churchill and improving the Port of Churchill in order to promote tourism and economic development in this region.

May 6, 1992

He said: Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the indulgence of the House in arriving a few seconds late on this. I was at a committee meeting and did not realize that the House would be moving so quickly through regular business.
I put this motion on the Order Paper and I am glad to have the opportunity to speak on it today because I feel that Canada is missing out on a great economic opportunity.
We have in this country a national goal to export more grain than we do at the present time. We know that the grain handling facilities that we have in this nation cannot handle all the grain that we wish to export.
Despite this fact, we have a situation where last year we shipped grain through Seattle. We have a situation in this country where the port of Churchill was underutilized at a period when there were strikes in Thunder Bay and at another period when there were strikes affecting the other ports of this nation.
The port of Churchill was open during both of those periods but it was not being used for the shipment of grain. For that matter, the port of Churchill was actually closed while one of these strikes was going on, even though the ice season had not returned to Hudson Bay or to the port itself.
We also have a situation where many of us who live on the prairies, especially the provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba, are not convinced that the federal government actively promotes the port of Churchill. For that matter, many of us are convinced that the officials of the Wheat Board, of Canadian National, and people within the Department of Transport actively work against the interests of the port of Churchill and the rail line going to that community.
I quoted examples before in this House up to and including the Minister Responsible for the Canadian Wheat Board with statements made by those officials where that minister had been completely incorrect, not just misleading but completely incorrect. Yet nothing is done.
We had a meeting in February of this year of supporters of the port of Churchill including residents from Saskatchewan, people from The Pas, from Churchill and other places in northern Manitoba, representatives of the Liberal caucus, the New Democratic Party caucus,
Private Members' Business
both federally and provincially from the province of Manitoba.
We met with the federal Ministers of Transport, both of them. We asked for two moratoriums, one a moratorium on actions by CN and by other government officials which were basically destroying the future of Churchill. By that I meant and used the example of rolling stock being sent out of the Churchill area so it was unavailable for wheat shipments.
We also referred to situations where branch lines which are very important for connecting grain to Churchill were being abandoned by CN. We said we needed a moratorium on that to make sure that the potential for Churchill was developed.
In addition, in our meeting with the ministers we said that we needed a moratorium on the negative remarks that were coming from government officials. We were not trying to censor. We were not trying to prevent people from exchanging honest views. We were saying take a look at what you allow government officials to say about the port of Churchill and ask yourself-we were talking to the Minister of Transport-if you would allow government officials to say the same negative things about the port of Montreal. Would you let them say the same thing about Thunder Bay? Would you let them say something as negative about facilities in Halifax? If it is a rail line, would you allow CN officials to say the same types of things about other tracks and operations they have in this country as they say about the tracks in northern Manitoba?
The government is so nervous about free expression by so many of its public servants. It is amazing how much is allowed when it comes to negative expression about the port of Churchill.
We in the north would not be upset if these negative expressions or negative statements were true. Time after time we have checked out these statements and found out that they were completely false.
The worst example of that was when the minister responsible for the Wheat Board was in front of the Saskatchewan Association of Rural Municipalities and he was asked a question. I listened to the tape carefully. He was asked why the Wheat Board did not use Churchill more often. The minister got up on his podium

May 6, 1992
Private Members' Business
and said: "Why, there are all sorts of reasons. Let me give you an example. Last year we had a ship from Brazil go up to the port of Churchill and it ran into an iceberg. We had to send technicians and welders up there to fix that ship up. As a result, the Brazilians do not want to use the port of Churchill next year".
It is true the Brazilians use the port of Churchill. It is not true that they do not want to use the port in the future. It is not true that the Government of Canada sent welders up there. And it is not true that any ship ran into an iceberg. The minister fabricated the story. He may have been misinformed, but what he said was completely incorrect. It never happened.
We brought this up after checking coast guard records for three consecutive years. It was revealed that there was a Brazilian ship that ran into an iceberg. It was outside the Gulf of St. Lawrence. It was not even near Hudson's Bay. The ship was not destined for Hudson's Bay.
That issue was raised twice in the House of Commons. We have had all sorts of municipalities and associations raising this issue. We have not had one correction from the minister responsible for the Wheat Board. Not one correction.
How can we expect government officials to give Churchill a fair hearing when the minister responsible for the Wheat Board will not do so? Two days ago, we had the results of the hearings that took place in various parts of Canada with regard to the future of grain in this country. It was noted that there was support from Saskatchewan and Manitoba for the port of Churchill, that the farmers there wanted to use the port.
There are things that can happen to improve that port, but what we need is some political vision. We have to have cabinet ministers assess it fairly, look at the capabilities and see what can be done for the future.
I see that my colleague for Winnipeg South Centre is in the House. When he was the Minister of Transport he worked with the province of Manitoba, the New Democratic Party government there, and he came up with a modernization program.
It was a federal-provincial agreement with agreements with CN as well, about how the port of Churchill was
modernized and made viable. A lot of work was done on that agreement but a lot of that agreement was not carried out. A lot of that work was not finished. Again, the government sat silently. It did nothing. It did not look at its economic options for the port of Churchill.
What we have called for is that the governments of Saskatchewan, Manitoba, the federal government, CN and the Wheat Board sit down and look at Churchill. Do not prejudge it; do not make rash statements which turn out to be false. Look at the options. Look at the benefits and see what can be done in that area.
In my motion we talk about tourism, other developments in the port, and the rocket range that has been developed in Churchill. We look at those things. We know the federal government wants to put a national park up there. But if we destroy the infrastructure in the meanwhile, none of those things will make any economic sense in the future.
If the rail line is ruined, why put a national park up there? If the port is destroyed, one of the reasons that tourists visit there will disappear. The reason for the community to exist diminishes. What we are saying is look at all of those options and then make a decision.
When those options are being looked at, we should take a look at some of the things that are happening in eastern Europe at the present time. We know that many of those nations need our grain. We know that many of those nations are cash poor. We know our federal government has signed an agreement with Russia to provide grain over the next five years. Those opportunities exist and are occurring. Yet nobody is looking at the fact that Churchill is closer both by rail and by sea to those ports that would receive our grain.
We also know the Russian ambassador wrote to the premier of Manitoba in February of this year explaining that many Russian ships are not busy at the present time. Many of the ships that are reinforced to travel in the north are not busy. In that letter, the Russians indicated they would be willing to look at using those ships in northern Manitoba to extend our shipping season.
Again, with that kind of proposal, that kind of offer, that kind of recognized market, why is the federal government not acting? There is a conspiracy of silence by this government when it comes to good work on behalf of Churchill.
May 6, 1992

If there is a negative remark to make, this government is willing to make it. It does not matter whether that statement turns out to be true in the long-run or not. We have had statements by a number of ministers of this government which have been negative to Churchill. They are made freely. Nobody checks the facts.
What we are saying is we do not want a guarantee that long-term funding is going to be provided to Churchill regardless of the facts. What we are saying is look at the facts, look at the economic opportunities, look at what is going to happen in this nation in the future and then make the decision as a government.
One of the things that upsets us the most at the present time is we know that there is nobody on the government benches who is really listening. We know that when opportunities are there, like the letter from the Russian ambassador, nobody on the government picks it up and runs with it.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
speechtext: We were busy.

Then we have some ridiculous remark from a member who does not know what he is talking about, as usual.
That is part of the problem that some of the constituents from my riding, from Saskatchewan and from Manitoba face. They are sick of being ignored. They are sick of having people make stupid remarks like that. What I have said is they want an honest hearing. What they want is the chance to explain what the value of Churchill is and they want the government to be listening because that is important to us.
We know that it is cheaper to ship grain from most of Saskatchewan to the port of Churchill. The rail line is shorter and basically downhill. We know that the water distance to many of our markets is also shorter. We recognize we have a shorter season, that is a reality. But we also know we can ship enough grain during that shorter season to not only have the port of Churchill make a profit at its operational end, but also to give a higher return to the farmers as well.
It is ironic that this government would allow the Wheat Board to ship grain through Seattle at the same
Private Members' Business
time that it made no effort to extend the season in the port of Churchill.
I know that my time has almost run out on this. What we are saying is that we want to see someone on the government side who will work for Churchill.
Let me say that the people who live in Portage-Interlake will ask why they elected a government member. The air base has disappeared and the rocket research that used take place in Churchill.
Guess what? Do you know where most of the employment took place? It was in Gimli, in a government member's riding. It seems to me that every time a government member is elected, all we have is another silent lamb, someone who is afraid to get up and say that the government is not paying attention to the concerns in the riding.
For that matter, I should point out that most of the ports in this country are held by New Democratic members anyway. Therefore, I do not think it is really a matter of competition.
What we are looking at is making sure that this country, this nation and, hopefully, this government will look at our economic opportunities, look at developing our grain trade, our tourist industry, developing the potential of this nation.
Again, it is ironic at a time when people are wrapping themselves in the flag with regard to the Constitution in this country that we are creating a sense of regional alienation by ignoring the opportunities that do exist in part of our country.
We only have one Arctic seaport in this nation. Instead of developing it, instead of looking at it as an economic opportunity, we have a government that basically says: "It is a headache. We do not want to deal with it".
What I am saying in this House and I have said it a number of times, is give Churchill a chance. I am asking this House to support a resolution that tells the government to give Churchill a real chance and a real look.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Richardson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Transport):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Well, that was pretty depressing. Mr. Speaker, perhaps now is the time for some optimism.
I am pleased to respond to the motion raised by the member for Churchill and to have the opportunity to

May 6, 1992
Private Members' Business
speak about what this government has done to promote the economic development of Churchill, particularly in
the tourism industry.
Churchill is well-known as western Canada's only northern deep sea terminal and is principally used for exporting grain. In recent years, however, the port has also been accommodating Arctic cruising by Society Expedition Ships.
Over the years, the people of Churchill have capitalized on its unique attributes, both man-made and natural. This has lead the community and its residents to overcome what may have been considered to be barriers, such as distance and climate. They have worked to improve the economy through innovative promotion of their community as a tourist destination.
Churchill is commonly known as the Polar Bear Capital of the World. As such, it attracts a sizeable number of tourists each year, including an increasing number from Europe and Asia.
Beluga whales and many species of migratory birds have also become major tourist attractions, especially for naturalists and related society expeditions.
From the viewpoint of the outdoor adventure product, this area can combine all the elements of a harsh but breathtaking landscape with educational and enjoyable, historical and cultural attractions.
Churchill has much to offer and has worked strategically with a great degree of sheer tenacity to achieve its status as a tourist site well worth exploring.
In terms of numbers, in 1989 a survey by Canadian Parks Service estimated attendance at Fort Prince of Wales alone to be in excess of 12,000 visitors.
As a responsible government we have to take into consideration that sustainable development of the area's natural resources is of utmost importance for long-term tourism and economic development.
With the possible addition and development of Fort Prince of Wales National Park, which is expected to benefit tourism over all, certain issues have to be addressed. Regulations for the use of the tundra must be developed and enforced.
It is largely the unique natural resources and wildlife viewing opportunities that attract visitors to Churchill. Therefore, future development of the park should proceed with caution and an assessment on the impact on
nature, natural and wildlife resources, should be considered.
We realize that Churchill has witnessed a significant increase in tourism activity in recent years. However, before any future development or expansion occurs it may be desirable for the community to conduct market research, a comprehensive assessment of the existing tourism infrastructure, including opportunities as well as constraints.
The region's ability to attract visitors and supply them with basic services such as transportation, food, lodging, outfitting, et cetera, influences the type and number of visitors to the area and, over the long term, will determine the extent of economic benefits.
As Churchill's tourism activity is currently highly seasonal, the economic viability of future tourism operations must be carefully studied.
As a responsible government, we have not been idle in working with the Churchill tourism community. Under the Canada-Manitoba Tourism Development Agreement major investments were made in the promotion of Churchill. The Government of Canada and the province of Manitoba supported cost-shared initiatives which included contributing to the construction of a 40-passenger tour boat, promoting wilderness tours through Arctic Experiences Ltd. and Frontiers North, supporting B & B scuba diving expeditions and funding a consortium to enable tour operators to market their tourism products effectively.
We also contributed to the development of a video cassette promoting Churchill, a wildlife viewing study and a wilderness adventure market study.
These are but a few of the projects which were undertaken during the last agreement.
The federal government and the province of Manitoba have recently signed a $10 million tourism agreement. Again, as in the last tourism agreement, Churchill will benefit. Already there are tentative plans to subsidize familiarization tours which will be attended by overseas travel organizations and tourism media.
We will be targeting the Japanese and German tourist market under the new program and will be promoting Churchill tour packages. There are also tentative plans for building an additional accommodation facility which is being considered by the private sector entrepreneurs and, to this end, the new tourism agreement may be considered for support.
May 6, 1992

We are aware that the economy of Churchill as well as the tourism industry depends on the continued service from an already limited transportation network. As most tourists today take trips of shorter duration, they tend to use airlines as their means of transportation to Churchill.
However, passenger rail continues to offer travel experiences for both those who have the time and inclination to tour by rail.
In conclusion, I want to emphasize to the people of Churchill that the people of Churchill can be assured that this government remains committed to supporting their efforts to build a diversified and sustainable economy for the future.

Mr. Speaker, listening to the member from Calgary South speaking on behalf of the government reminds me of some of those times you find yourself travelling away from home in a hotel room and you turn on the television set late at night and on comes a canned two-minute promo written by some tourist bureau writer which shows all the passion and commitment of a slick wax job.
I do not think the previous representative of the government knew what he was talking about or cared about what he was talking about. But I want to tell the House that there are people on the prairies who do. Churchill is an asset not just for the province of Manitoba but for the entire country. Historically, it was the place where the first Red River settlers entered Canada from Scotland. It was the entiy-way for the west, the first initial entrepot or gateway by which western Canada began to be settled in that area.
Since then it has always represented a major and distinctive transportation centre for the entire western-northern region of Canada until recently, until, as the member for Churchill has properly stated, it has been treated with cold neglect.
Yet at a time when we are presumably doing a careful assessment and review of the assets of this country as to what can help develop a different economy, one that is equally and broadly shared, I believe that Churchill does represent the catalyst by which we can open up, in part,
Private Members' Business
the north and in which we can also open up substantial trade opportunities to other parts of the world.
The member for Churchill mentioned that when I was Minister of Transport we signed an agreement with the then provincial government to modernize Churchill. It was the beginning because we had a fundamental belief that the port of Churchill was not simply for the benefit of the member for Churchill and his constituents but it was one of the keys that would unlock the door to western development. That is why we invested substantial moneys to improve the port, build a tug boat, and start adding to the infrastructure of that area.
Mr. Speaker, I want to point out one thing. The agreement was never completed because after 1984 the new government cancelled those provisions.
Let me give you an example. One of the most crucial elements in the continued existence of transportation to Churchill is the railway. We initiated through agreements some serious scientific experiments on how to deal with the permafrost plus initiated a renovation of the boxcars at the Transcona shops which would provide jobs for close to 1,000 people, and started the development of a new lightweight hopper car specifically designed for the Churchill line but also available for a number of other commodity carrying systems in Canada and around the world.
The researchers from industry and commerce who worked on it said it had the potential of offering manufacturing sales and export sales around the world because it was designed for countries which did not have highly urbanized dense transportation systems.
All that disappeared after July 1984. The then Minister of Transport, who is now our finance minister and likes to pride himself as being an advocate for the west cancelled out, wiped out, abrogated those provisions of the agreement that would have made Churchill a viable transportation centre.
I could not understand why the province of Manitoba did not take the government to court and force it to live up to a signed federal-provincial agreement. Right now we would not have to go through these silly arguments that we get from the railways and others that Churchill will not work. It would have worked under that agree-

May 6, 1992
Private Members' Business
ment. It would have had the basic infrastructure, the track improvement, and the box car systems. Not only that, we would have developed a new manufacturing industry for Canada. We would have established a niche that nobody else could have occupied.
That is why I find it so ludicrous at times when we hear the government talking about northern need to become more productive and competitive when in fact what it did was cancel out time after time initiatives that were taken. Why? Simply because they were taken by a Liberal government. It was an ideological decision and had nothing to do with ensuring that we would be competitive and productive in this country.
One of the other products of that agreement was some serious economic analysis as to the future of Churchill. What was pointed out was that in relation to the changes taking place in the north, as the hon. member for Churchill mentioned, the new developments taking place in eastern Europe and the republics of the former Soviet Union, that Churchill represented our best chip in playing in that game.
I just returned from a visit to Russia and Ukraine two weeks ago where we talked specifically about the new commercial linkages which could take place between western Canada and Ukraine, Russia, other republics. What they were proposing was the opportunity for joint enterprises to make the port of Churchill a substantial connecting link with those areas. They talked about the fact that they have the technology for ice-breaking, for reinforced ships, and they are prepared to put those in as part of a joint agreement between Canada and those republics to make the system work.
The irony is that those new governments and those new republics have more faith in the port of Churchill than the Canadian government has. They see a prospect for it. They see a future for it. The question is why cannot members opposite. Why can they not see its importance in giving western Canada a distinctive, unique opportunity that nobody else in North America has, to be able to ship our commodities and receive goods from those areas at a much lower cost than by going through the seaway.
It is a simple, economic fact. It does not mean to say that the seaway is not important, but what we really need to have is an interconnecting link of water transportation systems.
Instead there is an attempt to shut it down. I know some of the reasons, having been in the transport portfolio. There are very powerful interests who do not want to do it. They begin in the CN headquarters in Montreal; They have never liked the port of Churchill.
I do not know whether that is a corporate culture. Whatever it may be it is wrong. The only way to offset it in countervail is if there is a government prepared to say: "We believe in the port of Churchill. We want to invest in it. We want to use it".
As long as it is a Crown corporation-and God knows how much longer that will be because it is selling off all our assets-it will have to listen. That is why it is very important that some decisions be taken now.
Mr. Speaker, as a son of the west you also recognize the kinds of changes going on in that area. There are some new developments taking place in the prairie regions. There are some new feelings of co-operation in an attempt to bring the prairies together, to look at it as a region as a whole. How can we develop a distinctive transportation system in air, on sea and on land? How do we open up the north? How do we open up new trade links around the world?
I would suggest to members opposite if they have the ear of the Minister of Transport, the associate minister, or their parliamentary secretaries that they should make this part of a prairie decision. They should bring the provincial governments together and bring the concerned economic and labour groups together to work out a plan, of which Churchill would be a major part in developing those kinds of new commercial trade linkages.
That is the way to start innovating. That is the way to start opening up some new opportunities. They should start working in co-operation with that region. Rather than simply let the port of Churchill and its connecting links dwindle away, atrophy, we can turn the asset into a major opportunity.
However it does take some political will. It does take some commitment. It does take some engagement.
I support the member for Churchill on his initiative in this private member's motion. He is trying to bring focus and attention to that very fact. I do so because it is not a partisan issue. It is an issue for all of us in western Canada. It is an issue that each of us feels strongly about.
May 6, 1992

We know that if our region is going to modernize, survive and develop a new opening to the world in terms of trade at an efficient cost, we need the port of Churchill and all the things that string out from it.
It is not that alone. It can become one of the cornerstones, one of the foundations of a transportation system out of which tourism will flow, rocket ranges will develop and new scientific centres will emerge. I believe the opportunities for that area are limitless, but it will take an initial commitment to establish a firm foundation of a rail link and an air transportation link. Out of that the other development possibilities are limitless.
I want to endorse that point and hope that in this case members of the government are listening.

Mr. Speaker, I listened with interest to the debate that has gone on now.
I have an interest in this matter as my riding borders the seaway. It would be nice if there were enough grain flowing to the east that the seaway and the port of Churchill could be taken care of, but that is not the existing situation at this particular time.
We have to look at the entire transportation system in our part of the country, not consider just one aspect of it in isolation. As I say, it would be great if there were enough grain but there is not at the present time. The projections are that there will not be enough in the future. The seaway is crying out for more grain to go to the east as well. It would be terrific if it happened.
They have been dipping into their reserves for the last few years. They have experienced a downturn in the amount of grain that flows through the seaway. We have heard about the other things that have happened as a result, with portions of the fleet going out to sea and going into other service and whether there will be enough fleet capacity if the grain market should pick up. That is one question which has to be considered in this entire matter as well.
The indication was that the government has not even looked at this particular matter. That is not correct. In order to reassure the parties about this situation, on February 20, 1992 the Minister of Transport announced that the 1992 shipping season would commence on or
Private Members' Business
about July 24 in Churchill, depending of course on local ice and weather conditions.
In addition, the Minister of State for Transport is looking at the entire matter. She is in the process of collecting facts on the rail line, the port and the community. This is what is ongoing. This is what was requested by members of the opposition and the mover of the original motion. This exercise should provide a strong body of information with which future decisions about the facility can be made.
Throughout its modem history the port has essentially been a grain port and therefore in competition with the seaway. It used also to handle bulk imported cargo destined for the prairies until the seventies. The container revolution made this traffic uneconomical.
There are certain features about the port. The 140,000 tonne storage capacity grain elevator is the main feature. The harbour and loading berths can accommodate grain vessels loaded with up to 44,000 tonnes of grain. Open storage and shedded facilities are used for general cargo, and liquid bulk facilities are available for handling petroleum products. The port also has a secondary role in resupply operation to northern communities in the Keewatin district.
We had the opportunity in committee this afternoon to hear from a representative of CN Rail. We were looking at it in terms of moving grain, the seaway, and the general transportation system in eastern Canada. Questions were raised in that committee meeting specifically about the port of Churchill.
Some of the things that came out were interesting. The last speaker indicated that there was a study done and that it should be gone into in more depth. They looked at light rail cars and so on. In response to the questions that were asked, it was indicated that the rail line to Churchill is experiencing rapidly escalating maintenance costs. This is due primarily to dealing with the effects of the degradation of the permafrost on which the line is constructed. In addition to the permafrost portions, the southern portion of the line is in major need of rehabilitation.
One of the factors that the minister of state will take into account in assessing the situation is that the maintenance costs on this line are currently 70 per cent higher than the average cost on the grain branch lines. These permafrost conditions result in a sudden sinking of the track during the thaw in late summer and early fall which

May 6, 1992
Private Members' Business
unfortunately correspond to the grain shipping season. This is the time when the line should be used the most.
The reality is that the occurrence of these sink holes precludes the use of standard grain hopper cars on the route to Churchill due to the instability of these kinds of cars on the rough track. The individual from CN indicated in the committee that they are using older boxcars on this particular line. They are the type of car that is not used on any other line in the system. They are used on the route to Churchill for the short season each year.
One of the questions was: What happens to them the rest of the year? Do they just sit there and rust? That was the response that we got back this afternoon in regard to the port. That is going to have to be taken into account when we look at the entire transportation system of eastern Canada.
In 1990 the business revenue generated by the port's activities was approximately $14.45 million. It represents the revenue of firms and government agencies supplying cargo and vessel services, but excludes the value of cargo shipped through the ports. It is obviously an economic generator to the area and very important. The impact of the port amounted to just under $13.8 million, a half million dollars was direct income earned and approximately $9.3 million was re-spending by the employees. The total impact of the port is $4.7 million.
The port does have land for foreseeable industrial development and it can handle smaller-sized cruise vessels. However, the port facilities will need to be upgraded in order to provide better service for the tourists arriving by water when numbers justify the expenditure. By far the greater number of tourists arrive by rail and air.
The 1991 season was a pivotal year for the port of Churchill. Grain exports of 233,000 tonnes were only one-third the volume needed for break-even on operations. This was the fifth year in a row in which grain exports were insufficient to cover operating costs. Consequently, working capital reserves are now eroded to the point where further financial assistance is required if the facility is to stay open.
Commodities other than grain and re-supply cargo have been transported through Churchill from time to time. For example, some sulphur from Alberta was shipped through Churchill in the 1970s. As well, some exploration and drilling activities in and around Hudson Bay use Churchill as their supply base.
As I mentioned, interest has also been shown by some tour operators in Churchill as a port of call. A few vessels have called, but none in 1991. However, these activities contributed only marginally to the revenue base of Churchill.
The main focus of the port has been on grain. It is in direct competition with the seaway in that particular regard, and the seaway is also having its difficulties. In the past 10 years grain exports averaging 410,000 tonnes per year have contributed approximately 95 per cent of the port's revenue.
There was a substantial operating loss in 1984 and 1985, namely $2 million and $2.7 million respectively, resulting from low grain exports in those two years.
The Canada Ports Corporation approved a rationalization plan to reduce the potential loss in 1986. The rationalization program, coupled with a sharp increase in grain volume in 1986, resulted in an operating profit of $214,000 that year. However, in 1987 the tonnage was down and the port experienced a loss in that year of $342,000. In 1988 a record operating loss of $4.7 million resulting from the small volume of grain exports occurred.
Port working capital at the beginning of 1988 of $7.5 million dwindled by almost half leaving the port with only $4.5 million at the end of 1988. Since 1988 operating expenses have continued to be tightly controlled and the port has been able to reduce expenses by eliminating winter maintenance, laying off employees, and by general reduction.
The situation is that the port of Churchill needs approximately 600,000 tonnes of grain to achieve a break-even position. It would be great if that occurred. It would also be great if the rest of the grain could flow through the seaway and the seaway could show an operating profit. Both of these instances are self-sustaining, and they must continue to be self-sustaining.
May 6, 1992

I welcome the minister of state's examination of the port of Churchill. I am sure she will take into account the seaway and the entire transportation system of eastern Canada, and be fair in her assessment. I know the minister of state, I know that she will be fair and I am sure that the member will get the independent review that he is looking for in the context of the transportation of grain and other commodities in eastern Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to speak in favour of the motion posed by my colleague from Churchill which states:
That, in the opinion of this House, the government should consider the advisability of upgrading the rail link to Churchill and improving the Port of Churchill in order to promote tourism and economic development in this region.
Being from northeastern Saskatchewan, I and my constituents have an interest in seeing the further development of Churchill. This has been something that my parents generation and my grandparents generation have advocated for the region. We have always had some difficulty convincing CNR and the government this is a project that deserves some expenditure of moneys.
The current problem of shipping grain through Churchill is some parts of the rail line are bumpy because of the frost and an inadequate roadbed. It would take a few million dollars to fix that up so the heavy cars that are used over the rest of the rail system in western Canada could proceed to Churchill with full loads of grain, be competitive, and not require special equipment to get there.
There have been a couple of proposed solutions. One was the one the member for Winnipeg South has proposed; that of using aluminum hopper cars to keep the over-all weight of the load down so the amount of grain transported is competitive or similar in total tonnage to that that goes through the heavier steel hopper cars. The other would be to spend a little more money fixing the grade so regular traffic could make the trip to Churchill. That is the basic expenditure that needs to be made.
What we have seen is less than enthusiasm from the players in the grain business to make better use of Churchill. CNR does not seem to be particularly interested in expending any money on the track. When you
Private Members' Business
look at its operation you can fairly readily see sitting in its head office in Montreal, sitting on the edge of the seaway having expended money going east-west across the country, having got lots of money from the Government of Canada to maintain those rails, when it is faced with the choice of fixing this little northern link itself, it would rather not touch it.
As long as it can keep the grain moving on lines that have already been paid for by the government, it gives them a chance to show black at the bottom line instead of red. They do not have to worry about expanding business, watching a little bit of the grain drain out north to Churchill through a shorter water route and cheaper water route which only would put more money in the pockets of prairie farmers and not in the transportation system along the railways and the seaways that have been established.
I think the member for St. Catharines who spoke before me made that reasonably clear. The populated areas of Canada do appreciate having the grain come through their area and they enjoy taking their little bit for services as it goes through.
The choice for western Canadians is fairly straightforward. When we look at the costs involved, just as a simple comparison looking at the cost when we consider the money that went into the development of the seaway, and the east-west rail links compared to the pitifully small amount that it would take to link us into the Churchill route, we wonder why it was not done a long time ago.
Then we start looking at where the population is, where the economic power centres are, where the political power centres are, then we understand why Churchill is a fairly low priority of this government and among the economic elite of the country.
The development of Churchill would aid in the development of a new region. It would make the Churchill area in northern Manitoba more ready for development. It would open the area up for easier access to tourism, but mostly we see it as a smart use of money for economic development.
When you compare the cost of renewing the seaway over the next half century with the cost of transporting grain from central Saskatchewan or Manitoba through Churchill, even to trans-ship the grain and put it into a terminal elevator in the lower St. Lawrence, it still would

Private Members' Business
be much cheaper to do it that way than through the existing routes, but because the existing facilities are there the current power structure prefers to use the seaway, Thunder Bay and so on.
It has been a high volume method of handling grain. I think five or six years ago when I was through the port of Thunder Bay with the transport committee we were told that at that point in time Thunder Bay was still the world's largest grain port. More grain was handled through that facility on fresh water, but it compared with anything that was on salt water. It is still the world's largest grain port, handling more tonnes of grain in a year than any other port in the world.
The opportunity for maximizing returns is fairly high. However, that seaway route has run into some problems lately. More and more this government and the previous one as well have been saying that all of the costs of running the seaway and maintaining it have to be borne by shipping fees. There are a lot miles of water there that need maintenance. When you compare the Churchill option, there is not very much maintenance that is needed. Yes, the shipping season is a bit shorter, but the other operating costs will be extremely low compared to the seaway route if the country has to get to a point some day of deciding whether to do a complete rebuild on the seaway or the other option.
Because of the incrementalism that creeps into our economic structures, the twinning of the seaway will go on and Canada will continue to invest a lot of money in that option. It looks as if this government has decided there will not be very much go into the Churchill option.
I already pointed out that the main beneficiaries of the Churchill option are prairie farmers, mostly from the eastern and northern prairies, who would watch their grain be shipped over less than 700 miles of railway track as compared to over 1,000 miles to Thunder Bay. For some regions of the prairies, it is over 1,200 miles.
The transfer into ocean shipping would be similar. With very little extra we could handle at Churchill some of the world's largest grain ships. By putting a spout out into the deeper water, we could handle that kind of shipping.
We are told by the merchants and shippers and the people who make decisions in Montreal and Toronto that other countries do not like to put their ships through Hudson Strait into Churchill. That is an old argument.
At one time before a speech to the Hudson Bay Route Association 20 years ago when I was just a young farmer, I did a little bit of research before my remarks to the assembly. I dug out some derogatory comments about the shipping prospects for one of the regions of Canada which was published by the city of New York. It had virtually every argument that you hear out of Montreal and Toronto now levelled at Churchill. In fact it was not those ports, but it was in fact the port of New York warning shippers about the dangers of ice and icebergs and bad service because of ice and short seasons at the prospect of using Montreal instead of New York.
The propaganda war continues. It is just that that was a propaganda war of 150 years ago. We are getting into the 21st century when the possibilities of using Hudson Strait for longer and longer periods of time are very much alive.
The savings would be to western farmers. The savings would also be to purchasers, most likely in the northern European countries, particularly Russia. It could provide its heavy population, which is grain deficient, in the St. Petersburg area and areas north of Moscow, which could be easily serviced through Vladivostok, a port that is also an Arctic port. There would be no problems in navigating Arctic waters. The country has been missing an excellent opportunity to provide better service at remunerative rates to those customers in northern Europe and into northern Russia, as well as providing a cheaper service for the use of western Canadian farmers.
I realize where the votes are and where the money power is in this country but I think the country has been missing an excellent opportunity to do a good job of development which would be useful to western Canadians, the north, and our potential customers.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole

Pursuant to Standing Order 96(1), the order is dropped from the Order Paper.
It being eight o'clock p.m., this House stands adjourned until tomorrow at ten o'clock a.m., pursuant to Standing Order 24(1).
The House adjourned at 6.51 p.m.
Thursday, May 7,1992
